title: An AI-Enabled Decision-Making Model for Sustainable Production: Waste Reduction for Electronic Vehicle Battery Production of Multiple Products
affiliations: University of Birmingham, University of Birmingham, Georgia State University - Robinson College of Business, Arizona State University (ASU) - Supply Chain Management and University of Birmingham

detail.title: An AI-Enabled Decision-Making Model for Sustainable Production: Waste Reduction for Electronic Vehicle Battery Production of Multiple Products
detail.abstract: The rising popularity of electric vehicles (EVs) has brought the sustainability of battery production on the agenda, with waste reduction emerging as a critical concern. Existing research on waste reduction, however, has largely overlooked the non-linear factors influencing waste generation and the complexities of multi-product manufacturing. Given these gaps, our research develops a decisionmaking model that utilizes non-linear artificial intelligence (AI), explainable AI and simulation-based algorithm to identify waste sources and devise tailored reduction actions. Validated with production data from a leading battery manufacturer, our model prioritizes non-recyclable waste reduction by capturing variations in waste generation even in production processes that do not directly generate waste. The validation result suggests that the actions selected by our multi-product oriented model achieve more substantial improvement compared to existing linear models or single-product-focused approach. It improves the average super-efficiency DEA score from 0.95 to 1.23 (a 29.5% efficiency gain), while the proportion of non-recyclable waste decreased from 7.4% to 5.9%, demonstrating our model's superior performance in reducing waste and improving efficiency. For a 11 GWh factory, this translates to an estimated annual saving of $3.3 million in waste disposal costs. Accordingly, our research advances the production and process improvement literature on battery manufacturing by integrating a non-linear method to identify waste sources and adapting waste reduction strategies to the multi-product scenario. Additionally, by combining conventional AI with explainable AI, our decision-making model has better interpretability for the predictions of waste generation, offering a robust and practical method for waste reduction in battery production.

title: Global Cybersecurity Challenges for Students Using Online Learning in Higher Education
affiliations: University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria, University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria, University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria and University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria

detail.title: Global Cybersecurity Challenges for Students Using Online Learning in Higher Education
detail.abstract: This paper examines the critical cybersecurity challenges facing students in the rapidly expanding realm of online education. Following the unprecedented shift to digital learning platforms during the COVID-19 pandemic, educational institutions now store vast amounts of sensitive student data while frequently lacking robust security measures. We analyse the primary threats students face, including data breaches, phishing attacks, invasive monitoring tools, and vulnerabilities in outdated EdTech platforms. The research reveals that students are particularly susceptible to these threats due to limited cybersecurity awareness, poor digital hygiene practices, and inadequate institutional protections. Through examination of global case studies, including the 2021 Blackbaud ransomware attack affecting multiple universities and the University of York data breach, we highlight both the failures and successes in educational cybersecurity. The paper proposes comprehensive measures for educational institutions and EdTech companies, including implementing strong encryption, providing cybersecurity training, conducting regular security audits, and establishing ethical boundaries for student monitoring. As digital learning becomes permanently integrated into educational systems worldwide, this research underscores the urgent need for collaborative efforts between educational institutions, technology developers, and regulatory bodies to create secure learning environments that protect student data and privacy.

title: Lebanon's Economic Reconstruction: Institutional Innovation through Special Jurisdictions for Economic Recovery
affiliations: Institute and Faculty of Actuaries

detail.title: Lebanon's Economic Reconstruction: Institutional Innovation through Special Jurisdictions for Economic Recovery
detail.abstract: Lebanon's financial collapse since 2019, characterized by a 98% currency devaluation and over 50% GDP contraction, necessitates innovative solutions to overcome political gridlock. As the second paper in the series Reconstructing Economies in Crisis: Tailored Institutional and Geoeconomic Strategies for Financial Recovery, this study proposes five autonomous Special Economic Jurisdictions (SEJs) with independent legal frameworks, 0% corporate tax for ten years, and investment via $10 million zero-coupon infrastructure bonds. Developed in partnership with BRICS nations under a profit-sharing model, these jurisdictions leverage Lebanon's Mediterranean position to attract foreign direct investment, rebuild infrastructure, and achieve energy independence. Drawing on models like Dubai's DIFC and China's Shenzhen SEZ, this paper presents a phased, institutionally robust strategy to transform Lebanon into a regional trade hub, addressing political, security, and economic risks.

title: How Blockchain Reconfigures Supply Chain Dependence: Evidence from a Quasi-Natural Experiment
affiliations: University of Macau, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, University of Macau and University of Macau

detail.title: How Blockchain Reconfigures Supply Chain Dependence: Evidence from a Quasi-Natural Experiment
detail.abstract: Blockchain is widely promoted as a transformative technology for supply chain management, yet empirical evidence on how it reshapes inter-organizational relationships remains limited. This study investigates whether and how blockchain engagement alters firms' structural dependence on supply chain partners. Grounded in transaction cost economics, we conceptualize blockchain as a transaction-cost-reducing technology that lowers search, contracting, and monitoring costs, thereby enabling firms to reduce dependence on specific suppliers or customers. To identify causal effects, we exploit a quasi-natural experiment based on the staggered enactment of blockchain-supportive laws across U.S. states. Using two complementary difference-indifferences (DiD) estimators (specifically, a two-way fixed effects model and a two-stage DiD estimator), we find that firms exposed to such laws experience a significant reduction in both upstream and downstream dependence, with effects ranging from 6.7% to 15.0% relative to sample means. These findings are robust to double/debiased machine learning and a series of additional sensitivity checks. Further analyses reveal that blockchain's de-dependence effect is more pronounced in firms with higher levels of blockchain awareness or when managers are guided by risk-averse incentive structures. In extension analyses, we identify three distinct strategies through which firms likely operationalize the de-dependence: partner termination, multi-sourcing, and reduced collaboration intensity. We also uncover a mutual dedependence effect: blockchain not only reduces focal firms' dependence on partners, but also lowers partners' dependence on the firm. Overall, our findings offer novel evidence on how blockchain reshapes supply chain dependence, highlighting its strategic role in enabling interorganizational agility and reducing relational lock-in.

detail.abstract: Mathematical Programming (MP) is a well-established framework for formulating and resolving diverse optimization problems. An MP model integrates variables, constraints, and an objective function through mathematical expressions. Solving MP models relies on solver tools and scales up to millions of variables and constraints. The task of developing an MP model involves addressing subproblems such as discovering an MP model from domain knowledge, conformance checking of a candidate MP model with domain knowledge, and enhancing an invalid MP model based on domain knowledge. Traditionally, experts manually perform these tasks, leading to iterative processes that are both labor-intensive and error-prone. Recent literature highlights an emerging field of algorithms focused on automating MP model development using domain knowledge artifacts, which we jointly term MP model mining and divide into discovery, conformance checking, and enhancement problems. This study organizes and analyzes existing knowledge on MP model mining, aiming to elucidate the state of the art and pinpoint current gaps and challenges. Through a systematic review via an acknowledged literature search engine, we address 29 research questions concerning various dimensions, identify 16 knowledge gaps, and propose a future research agenda.

title: From solo to social: Understanding pathways to comobility
affiliations: Aalborg University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and ESCP Business School

detail.title: From solo to social: Understanding pathways to comobility
detail.abstract: Studies of joint employee transfers, termed comobility, emphasize the importance of these events for performance. However, we lack systematic knowledge of the comobility process and determinants, crucial to our understanding of social relations in the workplace. In this paper, we examine the configuration of network conditions and strategic actions that lead to joint versus solo employee mobility in the context of organizational failure. We use data from 21 unique, in-depth qualitative interviews on solo and social (i.e., joint) transfers into new jobs, combined with handpicked LinkedIn and media data on over 200 employees. We conduct crisp set qualitative comparative analysis (csQCA), and we find that social networks have limited relevance, compared to internal strategic action, as a core condition enabling comobility. In contrast, we find that in the absence of comobility, solo movers into new jobs are more likely to rely on their social networks instead of strategic action.

detail.abstract: This case study explores the optimization of overdue premium recovery processes at Zurich Santander Chile through the strategic use of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and digital automation tools. In an increasingly competitive and regulated insurance landscape, operational efficiency and financial traceability are critical. The study identifies existing bottlenecks in the collection cycle, with an average overdue premium recovery time of 12 business days and a recovery effectiveness rate of only 65%. Using a quantitative action-research approach, the author designed and implemented the KPI “Average Days to Recover Overdue Premium” (ADROP), integrated real-time dashboards via Power BI, and automated alerts through SAP and Power Automate. Preliminary simulations indicate a potential 50% reduction in post-overdue customer complaints and an improvement in recovery rates from 65% to 92%, translating into an estimated CLP $438 million in avoided losses. The study demonstrates the value of data-driven decision-making, continuous improvement cycles (PDCA), and system integration in enhancing financial and customer performance in the insurance sector. The proposed model is scalable to other processes and contributes to aligning operational actions with Zurich Santander Chile’s strategic goals.

title: Mixed Messages by Firms' Managers: An Exploration into the Strategic Use of Tonal Inconsistency across Managerial Financial Communications
affiliations: York University - Schulich School of Business

detail.title: Mixed Messages by Firms' Managers: An Exploration into the Strategic Use of Tonal Inconsistency across Managerial Financial Communications
detail.abstract: Using conference call transcripts and contemporaneous press releases for the same quarterly earnings announcement, I document that inconsistent managerial tone across these communication channels predicts future negative abnormal returns and influences the speed of market price responsiveness to earnings disclosures. My empirical results demonstrate that such tonal inconsistencies forecast significantly slower market reactions and are robustly associated with subsequent fundamental adverse changes in firm performance and profitability. I further find that these inconsistencies foster market ambiguity, thereby delaying investor responses and facilitating strategic and opportunistic insider trading that appears to capitalize on this delayed price incorporation. Overall, the evidence aligns with managers strategically employing mixed messaging in financial disclosures to mislead investors about underlying firm fundamentals by manipulating market perceptions and exploiting informational frictions induced by ambiguity.

title: Strategy as Ontology: From Metaphor to Mechanism in Strategic Thought
affiliations: Rhodes University

detail.title: Strategy as Ontology: From Metaphor to Mechanism in Strategic Thought
detail.abstract: Purpose To establish the ontological foundations of strategy and advance a falsifiable, cross-domain framework that transmutes metaphor into mechanism. Equips practitioners with tools to detect coherence drift, design adaptive architectures, and anticipate the inflection points of strategic timing. Originality / Value Recasts strategy as a measurable phenomenon of nature. It presents the first integrated, falsifiable ontology spanning micro-cognition to ecosystem dynamics-marking a decisive shift from heuristic bricolage to cumulative science.

title: Electoral Roll Inflation in West Bengal: A Demographic Reconstruction of Legitimate Voter Counts (2024)
affiliations: Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan - S.P. Jain Institute of Management & Research (SPJIMR) and Indian Institute of Management Visakhapatnam

detail.title: Electoral Roll Inflation in West Bengal: A Demographic Reconstruction of Legitimate Voter Counts (2024)
detail.abstract: This paper presents a demographic reconstruction of the legitimate voter base in the Indian state of West Bengal for 2024. Drawing on official data from electoral rolls, census, and civil registration systems, we estimate the surviving voters from the 2004 base roll, additions through new cohorts (1986-2006 births), and adjustments for net permanent migration. Our findings indicate that the 2024 electoral roll may include approximately 1.04 crore excess voters-an inflation of 13.69%. We apply intentionally conservative assumptions to establish a lower-bound estimate. The analysis has critical implications for electoral integrity and supports the case for a Special Intensive Revision in the state. Our methodology is replicable for nationwide applications.

title: Is IRS Form 990 A Reliable Data Source for Organizational Identity and Mission?
affiliations: LCC International University, Indiana University, Indianapolis and Indiana University, Indianapolis

detail.title: Is IRS Form 990 A Reliable Data Source for Organizational Identity and Mission?

contentType.other: This paper is part of the International Society for Third Sector Research (ISTR) Working Paper Features.

detail.abstract: Voluntary sector research often assumes that the IRS Form 990 accurately conveys key characteristics of nonprofit or non-governmental organizations (NGOs). Using a representative sample of international affairs nonprofits (n=262) from the nationally representative IRS microdata file, this study tests the reliability of 990 data for discerning an organization's identity. Specifically, we explore organizational religiosity because religion is a fundamental identity marker for many organizations, and scholars have difficulty systematically identifying religious NGOs. Our findings cast doubt on the accuracy of 990-mission data. It is a poor proxy for public mission statements. IRS Form 990-mission data also do not reliably convey an organization's religious identity or activity. However, a detailed analysis of Form 990 and supporting schedules detected religious NGOs with 85% accuracy-almost identical to the success rate of thorough searches of organizational websites. Thus, this paper offers caution and affirmation for researchers and policymakers using 990 data.

title: Muslim Philanthropy and Social Investment: A Study of Zakat Management in the MMCs in Asia
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Muslim Philanthropy and Social Investment: A Study of Zakat Management in the MMCs in Asia
detail.abstract: Social investment of Muslim philanthropy, especially in the management of waqf has been practiced, as studied by many scholars over the years. In the recent past, zakat has been an instrument of social investment in many Muslim majority countries. This is an analysis of the principles, regulations, features, and processes of social investment of Muslim philanthropy for its benefit maximization, as practiced in many MMCs in Asia. It is intended to create interest in further research, and attract philosophical and policy debates for adapting (or critiquing) social investment of Muslim philanthropy in other Muslim communities.

title: Optimal Fare Policy and Fleet Sizing for an Integrated Fixed-Route Transit and Microtransit System
affiliations: University of California, Irvine, University of California, Irvine, Students, University of California, Irvine, University of California, Irvine, Students and University of California, Irvine

detail.title: Optimal Fare Policy and Fleet Sizing for an Integrated Fixed-Route Transit and Microtransit System

declarations.funderStatement: This study was made possible with funding received by the University of California Institute of Transportation Studies through the Road Repair and Accountability Act of 2017 (Senate Bill 1).

detail.abstract: Integrating microtransit with fixed-route transit (FRT) can improve travelers' mobility by leveraging the benefits of microtransit's flexibility and FRT's high passenger capacity. However, the high operating cost of microtransit presents a challenge, which calls for a careful evaluation of the trade-offs between mobility gains and operational cost. To address this need, this paper develops a modeling approach and solution procedure to identify Pareto-optimal designs. We focus on design parameters of practical interest, namely, fare policies and microtransit fleet size. To explore these trade-offs, we propose a bi-level and bi-objective (i.e., minimize taxpayer subsidy and maximize mobility-based consumer welfare) modeling framework, with an agent-based transportation system simulation model at the lower level and a multi-objective Bayesian Optimization (BO) model at the upper level. We apply the modeling and solution approach to Lemon Grove, California (a suburban area in San Diego County). Results reveal a diverse set of solutions along the Pareto frontier, indicating that some naive microtransit fare strategies are suboptimal. Notably, Pareto-optimal designs feature a 50-100% discount for microtransit to FRT transfers, as well as peak-period fare multipliers between 1.8x and 3.5x to manage time-varying demand effectively.

title: Under Pressure: Strategic Signaling in Bank Earnings Calls
affiliations: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Federal Reserve Banks - Quantitative Supervision & Research, Stanford University and European Central Bank (ECB)

detail.title: Under Pressure: Strategic Signaling in Bank Earnings Calls
detail.abstract: Using local large language models, we document that bank earnings calls become more uniform in the topics discussed across banks, less forward-looking, and more negative in tone when financial conditions tighten. To account for these patterns, we develop a signaling game in which banks strategically choose between "reassuring" investors by echoing topics discussed by peers, or "promoting" their own distinct agendas. The model predicts pooling behavior during periods of financial stress and divergence when conditions stabilize, aligning with our empirical findings. An event study of abnormal returns around earnings calls further confirms that, in distressed times, banks that conform to industry narratives experience more favorable market reactions.

title: When Autonomy Backfires: Adverse Selection in Startup Recruitment
affiliations: Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania and University of Maryland - Robert H. Smith School of Business

detail.title: When Autonomy Backfires: Adverse Selection in Startup Recruitment
detail.abstract: While prior entrepreneurship research highlights strong preferences for autonomy among founders and early joiners of startups, little is known about how explicitly emphasizing autonomy in startup recruitment affects the composition of the applicant pool. We propose that such emphasis may inadvertently reduce applicant quality by disproportionately attracting lower-ability candidates while deterring higher-ability job seekers. This adverse selection may arise because individuals with varying cognitive abilities may interpret autonomy-related signals in systematically different ways. Specifically, lower-ability candidates may perceive autonomy at face value as desirable freedom from managerial oversight, whereas higher-ability individuals may infer potential organizational dysfunction, including ill-defined roles, insufficient managerial oversight, and unclear performance evaluation. Using large-scale job posting data, we first document that startups increasingly highlight autonomy in recruitment, particularly when targeting higher-ability talent. We then provide causal evidence for the proposed adverse selection through a field experiment conducted in partnership with a U.S.-based startup. Our findings reveal that, although autonomy is widely considered a desirable attribute that distinguishes new ventures from established firms, its explicit emphasis in startup recruitment may backfire—paradoxically deterring the high-ability candidates most critical to entrepreneurial success.

title: Lex Aegis: The Living Law- A Public Blueprint for Constitutional AI Governance
affiliations: SPQR Technologies Inc

detail.title: Lex Aegis: The Living Law- A Public Blueprint for Constitutional AI Governance
detail.abstract: As artificial intelligence assumes sovereign roles across society, its governance faces three existential frontiers: the necessity of public participation, the challenge of action in the absence of authority, and the complexities of plural, federated alignment. This paper integrates three distinct yet complementary doctrines, Lex Vox Populi (public participation), Lex Absentia (absence of authority), and Lex Concilia (federated governance), into a unified living law framework. Each doctrine addresses a critical governance frontier: how citizens shape AI (participation), how AI should behave without clear consent (absence), and how plural ethical systems can coexist (federation). Collectively, these doctrines form an adaptable, publicly accountable constitution for AI, bridging democratic legitimacy, operational constraint, and cross border cooperation. Building upon the Machine Republic framework pioneered by SPQR Technologies, we provide protocols, mechanisms, and public guidelines for encoding civic voice, constraining AI when legitimacy fails, and governing across multiple sovereign systems. This open blueprint invites policymakers, engineers, and civil society to participate in the future of AI constitutionalism, a living, challenging ready law system for the age of machine intelligence.

title: Guided Creativity: AI Intermediation for Enhancing Originality and Quality in Visual Design
affiliations: Northwestern University - Kellogg School of Management, Northwestern University - Kellogg School of Management and Kellogg School of Management, Northwestern University

detail.title: Guided Creativity: AI Intermediation for Enhancing Originality and Quality in Visual Design
detail.abstract: Creative fixation is a common side effect when designers seek inspiration from successful designs, often limiting the originality of subsequent work. This paper introduces AI intermediation, a novel approach that leverages generative models to overcome this challenge. Our approach creates variations of leading designs that maintain core semantic concepts while differing visually, and provides these variations to the designers instead of the original exemplars. This allows communicating valuable insights and inspiring novel interpretations without inducing fixation. We empirically validate the proposed approach using a field experiment involving professional designers in a logo design contest. Results show that designers with AI intermediation produce (1) higher-quality work than those with no exposure to exemplars, and (2) more-original work than those with direct exposure to exemplars. We further decompose the sources of creativity and demonstrate that while the generative model yields distinct variations, human creativity remains pivotal for improving originality and quality of the final designs. Consequently, AI intermediation presents an efficient facilitator to human-driven creative process.

title: Transportation for the Abundant Society
affiliations: Arizona State University (ASU) - Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law and Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning, The University of Michigan

detail.title: Transportation for the Abundant Society

publicationDetails.detailsText: Arizona State University Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law Paper No. 5383031
publicationDetails.journalName: Arizona State University Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
The abundance movement has rapidly gained traction as voices across the political spectrum seek to overcome artificial scarcity in housing, energy, and infrastructure. In all these areas, transportation policy is a binding constraint —yet with limited exceptions, it’s one the movement has overlooked. This Article seeks to fill that gap by showing that abundance cannot succeed without rethinking transportation policy from the ground up. While this suggests a big lift, it offers big rewards: once reconfigured, transportation policy can be a powerful accelerant of abundance.

At present, the signature goal of abundance advocates—amping up housing production—stands to collide with a key driver of scarcity: development restrictions fueled by traffic concerns. Building more housing in auto-dependent regions without reconfiguring transportation will reinforce the very logic of those restrictions. A mechanical application of the prime abundance directive—build more—would thus miss the mark: outside the exceptional case of high-speed rail, “more” is often the problem. (See urban renewal.) But “less” isn’t helpful either. What’s needed is a new approach.

Drawing on original interviews with leading transportation officials and scholarship in local government law and planning, this Article makes two key contributions. First, it proposes a theory of transportation for abundance. Abundance suggests that more is better, but its canonical accounts falter when defining the desirable “more” and what’s needed to support it. This Article intervenes with a concrete and scalable framework from urban planning: transportation access, which measures system performance by the ability of users to reach destinations. Though seemingly uncontroversial, anchoring policy in this objective would mark a revolutionary departure from a century of transportation planning.

The Article’s second contribution is to show that transportation reform is essential—not ancillary—to abundance, particularly for housing affordability, climate goals, and social equality. Transportation can’t stay in the backseat if abundance is the destination.

title: “Student Food Insecurities at Csu Chico and the Effects on Academic Performance”
affiliations: California State University Chico

detail.title: “Student Food Insecurities at Csu Chico and the Effects on Academic Performance”
detail.abstract: Food insecurity has emerged as a pressing public health and academic concern affecting thousands of college students across the United States. At California State University, Chico (CSU Chico), more than half of the student body identifies as food insecure, raising serious questions about how nutritional access may influence student success. This study investigates the relationship between food insecurity and academic performance among CSU Chico students. Guided by critical theory, the research explores how systemic inequalities and socioeconomic challenges contribute to disparities in academic outcomes. Using a randomized sample design and a structured online survey administered via the CSU Chico Qualtrics platform, the study collects nominal and ordinal data on student access to food and academic progress metrics. Statistical methods such as correlation coefficients and intraclass correlation will be used to assess reliability and uncover patterns within the data. The expected outcome is a clear correlation between food insecurity and lower academic performance, demonstrated through reduced class attendance, lower GPAs, and course withdrawal rates. The findings aim to inform targeted interventions and campus resource strategies, contributing to a more equitable educational environment for all CSU Chico students.

title: Navigating the Youth Frontier
affiliations: People Research on Indias Consumer Economy, People Research on Indias Consumer Economy and People Research on Indias Consumer Economy

detail.title: Navigating the Youth Frontier
detail.abstract:
India’s formidable 420-million strong population of youth embodies a reservoir of untapped potential. If nurtured,
the youth could power the country to realize its ambition of becoming a developed economy by 2047. This paper
delves into the evolving socio-political-economic-digital landscape of contemporary India, emphasizing the necessity
for strategic recalibrations to empower the youth. Beyond imparting skills and capabilities, the focus has to shift
to create an enabling environment that unleashes the full potential of this pivotal demographic. Recognizing the
aspirations of India’s youth is crucial for catalysing their transition into productive contributors to national growth.
Amidst technological advancements and the pervasive digital environment, policymakers face the intricate task
of designing targeted interventions that align with the evolving needs of the youth while leveraging technology
for inclusive development. The promise of India’s youth, however, is marred by significant disparities in access to
essential resources such as healthcare, education, gender equality, employment, and living conditions. Addressing
these inequities and investing in equitable resource distribution are imperative for harnessing India’s demographic
dividend and achieving developed economy status by 2047. This paper provides a comprehensive exploration of the
multifaceted landscape of India’s youth, analysing their economic status, aspirations, challenges, and opportunities.
By examining the perceptions, realities, and imperatives shaping the youth narrative, the paper offers insights into
the current status quo and highlights key factors for unlocking the transformative potential of India’s youth.

title: Expense Coding Syntax: Misclassification in AI-Powered Corporate ERPs
affiliations: Universidad de la Republica

detail.title: Expense Coding Syntax: Misclassification in AI-Powered Corporate ERPs
detail.abstract: This study examines how syntactic constructions in expense narratives affect misclassification rates in AI-powered corporate ERP systems. We trained transformerbased classifiers on labeled accounting data to predict expense categories and observed that these models frequently relied on grammatical form rather than financial semantics. We extracted syntactic features including nominalization frequency, defined as the ratio of deverbal nouns to verbs; coordination depth, measured by the maximum depth of coordinated clauses; and subordination complexity, expressed as the number of embedded subordinate clauses per sentence. Using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), we identified that these structural patterns significantly contribute to false allocations, thus increasing the likelihood of audit discrepancies. For interpretability, we applied the method introduced by Lundberg and Lee in their seminal work, “A Unified Approach to Interpreting Model Predictions,” published in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 30 (2017): 4765–4774.

title: Uniforms Behind the Curtain: A Comparative Study of Military Influence on Governance in Seven Big Nations (1995-2025)

detail.abstract: This comparative study investigates the extent and evolution of military influence on governance in seven strategically significant nations-Pakistan, China, Russia, the United States, North Korea, Egypt, and Algeria-over a 30-year period (1995-2025). While some of these states operate under formal democratic structures and others under authoritarian regimes, each displays varying degrees of military involvement in political processes, institutional control, and economic activity. The paper adopts a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative case study analysis with quantitative indicators such as the Global Militarization Index (GMI), military expenditure as a percentage of GDP, and the Multidimensional Measures of Militarization (M3). The study explores the political economy of military establishments, their constitutional and extraconstitutional roles, and the mechanisms-both visible and covert-through which they shape national policy. It introduces a Military Influence Index (MII) to systematically compare the countries based on institutional presence, economic control, policy dominance, and security enforcement. Findings reveal stark contrasts: countries like North Korea and Egypt exhibit overt military control, while in the United States, influence is institutional but restrained by civilian oversight. Pakistan and Algeria demonstrate hybrid models, where civilian governments function under latent or conditional military approval. The study highlights the global persistence of military influence in civilian governance and its implications for democratic consolidation, political accountability, and civil liberties.

title: Estimating State Space Models: Simple Corrections for Finite Sample Bias
affiliations: CREATES, Aarhus University, Aarhus University and University College London

detail.title: Estimating State Space Models: Simple Corrections for Finite Sample Bias
detail.abstract: This paper introduces new methods to adjust for finite sample biases in estimators of potentially nonlinear and non-Gaussian state space models without repeatedly optimizing the log-likelihood function. Stability of the bias adjusted estimates is enforced using either a data-driven shrinkage procedure or the indirect inference approach to bias adjustment. The methods are tested on i) a factor model, ii) a Gaussian affine term structure model, iii) a multivariate stochastic volatility model, and iv) a quadratic term structure model. The simulation results show that the methods give lower bias and lower root mean squared errors when compared to the (quasi) maximum likelihood estimator.

title: Return Stacking and Portable Alpha, an Investor's Guide
affiliations: Auspice Capital and Auspice Capital

detail.title: Return Stacking and Portable Alpha, an Investor's Guide
detail.abstract:
This paper examines the evolution of portfolio construction through portable alpha and return stacking, approaches that enhance diversification and capital efficiency while preserving core market exposure. Portable alpha, long employed by large institutional investors, separates beta and alpha by using derivatives or managed accounts to overlay uncorrelated return streams on top of traditional market exposures. Return stacking represents a modern and more accessible extension of this approach, using commingled funds and futures-based strategies to provide dual exposure. Investors can maintain equity, fixed income, or other asset participation while adding complementary strategies such as trend-following CTAs, on top.

The paper reviews the historical development of these techniques, including early institutional implementations and public market examples such as PIMCO StocksPLUS and the Catalyst/Millburn Hedge Strategy Fund. It explores the potential benefits of return stacking, including improved risk-adjusted and absolute returns, greater capital efficiency, and behavioral advantages that can help investors maintain discipline. It also highlights key considerations such as style risk, conditional correlations, and the use of leverage.

Through historical examples, stress periods, and illustrative portfolio outcomes, this paper provides a framework for investors seeking to integrate uncorrelated return streams into traditional allocations in a practical and scalable way.

declarations.funderStatement: The project from which this article results has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation program (grant agreement No 817652).

detail.abstract: This article argues that measures that are harmful to the climate or state inaction on climate change constitute a violation of the non-discrimination guarantees in international human rights treaties because they discriminate against future generations. The article defines future generations as a group of individuals that are yet to be born as well as children under 18 years of age because they lack political representation. The core of the argument proceeds in three steps: First, the article demonstrates that action or inaction harmful to the climate constitutes age discrimination. Future generations are a vulnerable group in the sense of nondiscrimination law because they suffer from political disadvantage due to their underrepresentation in the political process. Second, measures harming the climate are usually indirect discrimination. International human rights bodies generally recognize that indirect discrimination can violate non-discrimination norms. Saving costs today by imposing them on future generations would not be an adequate justification because of the power-asymmetry between present and future generations. Finally, the article differentiates between state measures that harm the climate and inaction on climate change. Measures that are actively harmful, such as fossil fuel subsidies, can usually not be justified. When it comes to state inaction, courts often derive positive obligations from human rights norms. However, states enjoy a wide margin of appreciation. Therefore, courts cannot impose concrete obligations on states. They do not turn into an ersatz legislature. Instead, they can impose a general obligation to act that nudges the political process.

detail.abstract: The paper delves into the integration of Work-Integrated Learning (WIL) and innovative pedagogical practices within pre-service teacher education programs. It seeks to uncover synergies between real-world experiences and classroom-based instruction, creating a holistic learning environment for aspiring educators. By intertwining theoretical foundations with hands-on experiences, this paper aims to equip future teachers with the skills, knowledge, and adaptability needed to navigate the complexities of modern educational settings. The exploration of innovative pedagogical practices will encompass the infusion of technology, collaborative learning methodologies, and learner-centred approaches. It will shed light on how these practices can be seamlessly embedded into teacher education curricula to enhance the teaching skills and adaptability of pre-service educators. The paper emphasizes the critical role of industry-academia collaboration in shaping the future of teacher education. Through partnerships with schools, educational institutions, and industry stakeholders, pre-service teachers can engage in authentic learning experiences, bridging the gap between theory and practice. The findings and recommendations presented in this paper aim to provide a roadmap for educational institutions, policymakers, and teacher educators to rethink and redesign pre-service teacher education programs. Ultimately, the goal is to foster a cadre of future-ready educators who are not only well-versed in educational theory but are also adept at applying innovative pedagogical practices through a seamless integration of Work-Integrated Learning experiences. This thematic paper contributes to the ongoing discourse on the evolution of teacher education in the context of an ever-changing educational landscape.

detail.abstract: The development of regional investment infrastructure largely determines the rates of economic growth, the level of prosperity, and the quality of life of the population. An optimally structured investment infrastructure, built on the principles of fair competition, will become an effective tool for accumulating investment resources to ensure accelerated economic growth based on economic diversification, leveling regional development disparities, and improving the quality and standard of living of Russian citizens. Assessing the development of investment infrastructure is relevant because it allows identifying changes leading to positive results in the formation of scientific and technological leadership, which is the foundation of a state's economic sovereignty.

title: Prone to Contagion
affiliations: Rice University - Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Business and Rice University

detail.title: Prone to Contagion
detail.abstract: We examine how shocks to the supply of US Treasuries (UST) impact long-term foreign sovereign bond prices. Leveraging the suspension of 30-year Treasury bond auctions from 2002 to 2006 as a natural experiment, we employ a quantity-driven term premium model incorporating limits to arbitrage. Our results indicate that reduced UST supply elevates UST prices and decreases foreign bond yields. The contagion effect intensifies with higher correlations between US and foreign short-term rates, reinforcing the limitsto-arbitrage framework in global markets.

title: Do Retail Information Awareness and Acquisition Costs Matter for Market Liquidity? Evidence from Mandatory Investor-Firm Interactions
affiliations: Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Southwestern University of Finance and Economics, Monash University and RMIT University

detail.title: Do Retail Information Awareness and Acquisition Costs Matter for Market Liquidity? Evidence from Mandatory Investor-Firm Interactions
detail.abstract: We examine whether retail information awareness and acquisition costs (RIAAC) affect market liquidity using mandatory interactions between Chinese listed firms and retail investors that reduce these costs. We find significant reductions in market liquidity measured by trading volume, stock turnover, price impact, and bid-ask spread. Furthermore, we observe significant decreases in return volatility but no changes in investor disagreement, suggesting that the reduction in noise trading drives the observed decrease in liquidity. Using accountlevel data, we document that retail trading decreases after the interactions. The reduction in liquidity is not due to changes in firm disclosures. Finally, we find that stock prices exhibit additional reactions to previously announced earnings surprises following the interactions, suggesting that reducing RIAAC accelerates the incorporation of neglected information into prices.

detail.title: Financial Inclusion and Bank Performance: Assessing the Mediating Effect of Financial Development in Sub-Saharan Africa

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Authors received no financial support for the research, authorship and publication of this article

keywords.keywords: Bank performance; financial inclusion; financial development; mediation analysis; sub-Saharan Africa.

detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between financial inclusion, financial development, and bank performance in Sub-Saharan Africa, with a focus on the mediating effect of financial development. Using a panel data from 42 sub-Saharan Africa countries, with a sample of 2100 observations from the World Development Indicators from 1990-2024, the study employs structural equations modelling of Baron and Kenny (1986) mediation analysis approach to investigate the relationship between financial inclusion, financial development, and bank performance. The results indicate that financial inclusion has a significant positive impact on bank performance, accounting for approximately 70.7% of the variation in bank performance. However, the relationship between financial inclusion and bank performance is mediated by financial development which plays a critical role in enhancing bank performance. The Sobel Test confirms that the mediation effect of financial development is statistically significant. The study's findings have important implications for policymakers and financial institutions seeking to promote financial inclusion and improve bank performance in sub-Saharan Africa. The results suggest that financial development is a crucial mechanism through which financial inclusion affects bank performance and that policymakers should prioritize initiatives that promote financial development to enhance bank performance.

title: Shocks to Income in a Lifecycle Model: An Undervalued Risk
affiliations: Morningstar

detail.title: Shocks to Income in a Lifecycle Model: An Undervalued Risk
detail.abstract: Lifecycle models are increasingly popular in financial planning. However, they often overlook the significant risk posed by income shocks-such as career disruptions, economic downturns, or technological advancements-that can affect financial plans, including retirement. This paper explores the role these shocks have on shaping saving rates, financial capital accumulation, and asset-allocation decisions, with particular attention to the possible relationship between income shocks and equity returns. By integrating industry-specific income risk into asset allocation decisions, this research provides practical insights for financial advisors seeking to personalize investment strategies based on clients' career paths, education levels, and industry volatility. The findings suggest that adjusting for income shocks can significantly improve retirement planning and improve alignment of asset allocations with clients' financial stability by increasing saving rates and adjusting equity exposure in portfolios.

title: Do ESG ratings guide retail investor decision making? Evidence from shocks to the availability of free ESG ratings
affiliations: University of Cincinnati - Lindner College of Business, University of Tennessee, Haslam College of Business, Accounting and Information Management and Hong Kong Polytechnic University

detail.title: Do ESG ratings guide retail investor decision making? Evidence from shocks to the availability of free ESG ratings
detail.abstract: Demand for Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) information has expanded the market for ESG ratings, but whether these ratings guide retail investor decision making is unclear. To examine this question, we exploit four plausibly exogenous events when major ESG rating agencies began providing their ratings to the public at no cost. We find that retail trading volume and the number of retail trades increase significantly following these events. The effects are more pronounced among high-attention firms and firms with lower ESG transparency. We also find that retail investors make larger net purchases when the newly released ESG ratings convey positive news and that subsequent net retail demand positively predicts future returns. Overall, our study demonstrates that ESG ratings significantly influence retail investor trading decisions and suggests that processing costs, rather than a lack of interest, may be the primary barrier to retail investors incorporating ESG information into their investment strategies.

title: Managing Aggrievement
affiliations: Rice University - Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Business, Rice University and Columbia University - Columbia Business School

detail.title: Managing Aggrievement
detail.abstract: Aggrievement occurs when groups have grounds for complaint due to unfair treatment. Although theory suggests central planners manage aggrievement when allocating resources, empirical evidence is scarce. We address this gap by examining governors' selections of Opportunity Zones (OZs)-investment tax breaks for eligible low-income tracts. We develop a structural model, validated by a national survey of local officials. Incorporating county aggrievement improves model fit in 38 states. Managing aggrievement affects three million OZ residents, leading to OZs with 28,110 fewer poor families and 637,983 (371,667) fewer Black (Hispanic) residents. OZs selected to manage county aggrievement generate 47% less equity investment.

title: Stablecoins as a Catalyst for Democratizing Gaming Payments and Beyond
affiliations: CGT Capital Group, LLC. and CGT Capital Group, LLC.

detail.title: Stablecoins as a Catalyst for Democratizing Gaming Payments and Beyond
detail.abstract: The rapid evolution of digital payments has ushered in a new era for the gaming industry, with stablecoins such as RLUSD and USDC emerging as pivotal instruments for reducing transaction friction and democratizing access to global gaming economies. Designed to maintain parity with the U.S. dollar, these blockchain-based assets offer a compelling alternative to traditional fiat-based systems dominated by legacy payment processors like Visa and Mastercard. This paper examines how stablecoins address long-standing challenges in gaming payments, including high transaction fees, cross-border friction, and exclusion of underbanked populations-by enabling instant, transparent, and low-cost settlements. It also explores the transformative potential of stablecoin integration in future gaming ecosystems, including the tokenization of in-game assets and the rise of decentralized creator-driven economies. Through the lens of financial decentralization, institutional adoption, and global accessibility, this paper argues that stablecoins are positioned not merely as alternatives, but as essential infrastructure for the next generation of digital commerce in gaming and beyond.

title: Exploring the Effect of ODA on Poverty: Insights from Least Developed Countries
affiliations: The University of the South Pacific and The University of the South Pacific

detail.title: Exploring the Effect of ODA on Poverty: Insights from Least Developed Countries
detail.abstract:
The purpose of this study is to examine the long run impact of Official Development Assistance (ODA) on Poverty levels in a sample of 33 Least Developed Countries (LDCs) from 1991-2018.
This study employed second generation panel econometric techniques like Westerlund (2007), Pedroni (2004) cointegration tests and the AMG (Eberhardt and Bond, 2009); (Eberhardt and Teal, 2010) and FMOLS (Phillips and Hansen ,1990) estimations to ascertain long run nexus between the variables of interest.
Our findings revealed that ODA has a significant and positive impact on poverty expansion in LDCs. This indicates that ODA perpetuates poverty in LDCs in the long run. While GDP per capita and trade openness significantly contributed to reducing poverty levels. Our findings have several policy implications.
This paper sheds light on panel of LDCs on which research on ODA-Poverty nexus is sparse in prevailing literature. Although studies have documented the impact on single country episodes on LDCs, research on panel of LDCs remains largely unexplored. This is surprising given the heightened economic and social issues faced by these cross sections. Additionally, a sustained downturn in ODA flows to LDCs and the commitment to meet SDG Goal 1 underscores the need for comprehensive analysis on LDCs. Hence, our study aims to address the critical gap in the prevailing literature and contribute to the field.

title: Food Poverty in African Countries: Examining the Dual Challenge and the Interplay between Energy Utilisation and Ecological Sustainability
affiliations: Federal University Wukari and Nnamdi Azikiwe University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Food Poverty in African Countries: Examining the Dual Challenge and the Interplay between Energy Utilisation and Ecological Sustainability
detail.abstract: Despite various policy interventions, food poverty (FP) remains widespread across the African continent, exacerbated by limited access to modern energy use and harmful ecological practices. This study therefore not only examines the effects of energy consumption and environmental sustainability, but also explores how the interaction between energy use and ecological sustainability influences FP in Africa. Data from 42 African countries, spanning the period 1990 to 2021, were analysed using the method of moments quantile regression technique. Empirically, the study demonstrates that improved energy use and ecological sustainability reduce FP in African economies, particularly in contexts where FP is less severe. However, the mitigating effect of environmental sustainability on FP is consistently greater than that of energy consumption across all quantiles. Conversely, the interaction between energy use and ecological sustainability reveals a reinforcing effect on FP. Further findings show that when food production is exclusionary, unsustainable, and exploitative, it exacerbates FP. Additionally, while income and population growth significantly intensify FP—particularly in African countries with low to moderate FP intensity—the effect of income is relatively marginal. Drawing on these findings, the study outlines policy interventions that African economies can adopt to address FP effectively.

reference: Willamette Journal of International Law and Dispute Resolution, Volume 32, No. 2, 2025, pp. 83–118
title: Political Will, Implementation, and Institutional Reform in the African Transitional Justice Pursuit
affiliations: Harvard University - Harvard Law School

detail.title: Political Will, Implementation, and Institutional Reform in the African Transitional Justice Pursuit

publicationDetails.detailsText: Willamette Journal of International Law and Dispute Resolution, Volume 32, No. 2, 2025, pp. 83–118

detail.abstract: In the wake of the Cold War, with foreign political powers cloistering for the dominion to steer freshly decolonized African states, the United States and other Western players employed strategies of international law to secure influence that appeared then uncertain in the face of newfound African liberation. As inter-African and intra-African conflict ensued as a result of these interferences, international stakeholders turned to transitional justice as a primary mechanism of restoration and reconstruction in the early 1990s. Since then, Africa has witnessed almost half of its States adopt transitional justice measures, namely truth and reconciliation commissions (TRCs), with arguably little tangible success. This article explores the limitations of these former transitional justice processes, particularly their failure to prioritize the institution-building pillar of transitional justice, incorporate the voices of local citizens, and implement the formal recommendations of TRC final reports—which are often the manifestations of years of research and community engagement. A crucial first step in ensuring the effectiveness of transitional justice processes in Africa is building on the efforts of existing institutions and local expertise to overcome challenges on the ground. In so doing, this article emphasizes the power and potential for positive change through the international community and African governments seriously monitoring the implementation of recommendations that emerge from the transitional justice process. Genuine commitment to the transitional justice process in Africa must be demonstrated not only in initiating transitional justice but also in reacting effectively to the findings of the process to combat the fragility of African states in governance, public trust, and the rule of law.

title: Patent Pending or Patent Granted? How Green Innovation News Shapes the Economy
affiliations: Lancaster University - Lancaster University Management School

detail.title: Patent Pending or Patent Granted? How Green Innovation News Shapes the Economy
detail.abstract: We study the macroeconomic effects of green technology news shocks using novel UK patent data. We construct novel instruments based on published and granted patents, distinguishing green from total innovation. We find that signals from published green patents (still pending and not yet granted) reflect greater uncertainty and imply recessionary effects and a decline in productivity, whereas news on green innovations based on granted patents raise productivity and output overtime. Over time, sector-level responses confirm these asymmetries, highlighting how the timing and viability of green innovation shape economic outcomes. A DSGE model with endogenous uncertainty and an option to delay investment and hiring explains the differential effects of green news shocks based on published versus granted patents.

detail.abstract: The AI Clinical Safety Act of 2025 establishes the first comprehensive federal framework for transparency, auditing, and accountability in artificial intelligence and machine-learning systems used for clinical decision-making in the United States. The Act mandates public explainability summaries, independent risk-scaled audits, and real-time drift monitoring for high-risk tools. Hospitals and vendors must log and report clinician overrides and adverse events, while vendors meeting rigorous audit and transparency standards are eligible for expedited FDA review and liability protection. The Act includes strong anti-gaming provisions, randomized spot audits, whistle-blower rewards, and a five-year sunset with GAO evaluation. By combining transparency, robust independent oversight, and carefully structured incentives, the AI Clinical Safety Act aims to safeguard patients, prevent bias and drift in clinical AI, and foster responsible innovation. This bill provides a statutory template for building trust and safety as AI systems become foundational in modern medicine.

title: Dynamic Cost-Benefit Analysis: A New Framework for Evaluating Policy Impacts
affiliations: America First Policy Institute (AFPI)

detail.title: Dynamic Cost-Benefit Analysis: A New Framework for Evaluating Policy Impacts
detail.abstract: Traditional cost-benefit analysis (CBA) is rooted in static equilibrium concepts, capturing welfare at a single point in time. However, many policies unfold over long horizons, influencing future production, investment, and intergenerational welfare. This paper proposes a Dynamic Cost-Benefit Analysis (Dynamic CBA) that builds upon traditional static methods while explicitly tracing how benefits and costs evolve across multiple periods. By extending concepts like consumer surplus, producer surplus, deadweight loss, and externalities into a dynamic context, Dynamic CBA provides a richer understanding of welfare impacts than traditional static methods. Challenges to implementation include contending with uncertainty, discounting controversies, and institutional resistance to change. The paper concludes by responding to these concerns and offering directions for future research to better align policy evaluation with dynamic economic realities.

title: An Analysis of the Role of Nigerian Copyright Commission as a Designated Relevant Organisation under the Proceeds of Crime Act, 2022
affiliations: Independent and University of Abuja

detail.title: An Analysis of the Role of Nigerian Copyright Commission as a Designated Relevant Organisation under the Proceeds of Crime Act, 2022

publicationDetails.detailsText: Global Journal of Politics and Law Research, volume 13, issue 3, 2025[10.37745/gjplr.2013/vol13n3118]

detail.abstract: This study investigated the nexus between copyright offences and criminal proceeds in Nigeria. It focused on the expanding role of the Nigerian Copyright Commission (NCC) as a designated Relevant Organisation (RO) under the Proceeds of Crime (Designation of Nigerian Copyright Commission as a Relevant Organisation) Order, 2025. The Order is made pursuant to section 81 of the Proceeds of Crime (Recovery and Management) Act, 2022 (POCA). The study highlighted the growing prevalence of copyright infringements. The highlight includes their significant economic implications, particularly in the digital era where such offences can presumably be linked to organised crime and money laundering. The objective was to examine how NCC's powers have evolved from traditional civil enforcement to include criminal prosecution and asset recovery within Nigeria's broader anti-money laundering framework. The research found that copyright offences, while not explicitly listed as predicate offences under anti-money laundering laws, are effectively treated as such due to their association with illicit financial gains. It further found that the designation of NCC under POCA is to enhance enforcement capabilities. This will empower NCC to conduct asset tracing, seizure, and management connected to copyright violations. The study recommended strengthening institutional collaboration between NCC and financial intelligence agencies, improving legal frameworks to explicitly include copyright offences as predicate crimes, and enhancing capacity-building for effective enforcement. In conclusion, NCC's integrated enforcement role is pivotal in disrupting the economic benefits of copyright crime and advancing Nigeria's fight against organised economic offences.

title: Will the Indian Youth Pay an Equal Amount for an Indian Brand or an Indian-Made Product as They Would for a Foreign Brand? A Dive into the Spending Psychology of the Indian Youth
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Will the Indian Youth Pay an Equal Amount for an Indian Brand or an Indian-Made Product as They Would for a Foreign Brand? A Dive into the Spending Psychology of the Indian Youth
detail.abstract: India's consumer landscape is experiencing a notable shift, particularly among its rapidly growing youth demographic. While global brands have long held prestige-often associated with quality, style, and social status-this dynamic is shifting. Factors such as increased local pride, government initiatives like "Make in India" and "Vocal for Local," and the influence of social media are reshaping how young Indians perceive and interact with brands. This research explores whether Indian youth are genuinely willing to spend the same amount on Indian brands as they do on international ones. Drawing insights from a primary survey of over 125 respondents aged 15 to 25, the study captures authentic youth perspectives on brand preference and spending behavior. It also incorporates secondary research from sources such as Mintel, McKinsey & Company, and the Boston Consulting Group to frame the findings within a broader economic and psychological context. The results highlight a thoughtful but cautious consumer mindset. While many young Indians express patriotic sentiments and a growing willingness to support local products, their purchasing decisions are still significantly influenced by perceived quality, social pressure, and the aspirational appeal of foreign labels. Indian brands are steadily gaining trust and traction-particularly in food, personal care, and apparel-but will need to continue building credibility and emotional resonance to compete with established global names fully.

title: Delegated Cash Storage Model: The Role of Authorized Banks in Ensuring Ukraine's Financial Stability: Case Study of PrivatBank JSC CB
affiliations: Association for Financial Professionals (AFP)

detail.title: Delegated Cash Storage Model: The Role of Authorized Banks in Ensuring Ukraine's Financial Stability: Case Study of PrivatBank JSC CB
detail.abstract: This article analyzes the delegated model of cash management and storage of the National Bank of Ukraine's cash reserves in authorized banks. The model is based on transferring a portion of the central bank's functional responsibilities for the physical safekeeping and operational management of cash to selected banks. Drawing on the provisions of NBU Regulation No. 408 (2016) and the author's years of experience at PrivatBank-the largest bank in Ukraine-the article explores the model's impact on financial stability, cash logistics, and the resilience of the banking system. Particular attention is paid to institutional trust between the regulator and banks, the risks and advantages of the authorized storage model, and operational mechanisms ensuring continuity of cash circulation during periods of crisis, systemic instability and war.

title: Green Jobs and Green Economic Development in Kigali's Construction Value Chain: Evidence from a Firm Survey
affiliations: German Institute of Development and Sustainability (IDOS), German Institute of Development and Sustainability (IDOS), University of Rwanda, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Green Jobs and Green Economic Development in Kigali's Construction Value Chain: Evidence from a Firm Survey
detail.abstract: Green, circular buildings are crucial for climate change mitigation and resource efficiency, yet their employment impact in Sub-Saharan Africa remains unclear. This paper explores green job potential in Kigali, Rwanda—an urbanizing city with strong policy commitments and urgent housing needs. Employing a sequential mixed-methods design, we conducted 33 expert interviews and surveyed 546 firms across five construction value chain segments. We find that (1) many green jobs already exist, with 5.1% highly green and about 58% partly green based on practices performed; (2) green and circular practices are emerging through both policy support and grassroots innovation, (3) greening is positively, significantly correlated with employment growth for highly green firms, and (4) greening is significantly associated with improved job quality for all firms. Targeted support for firms in critical greening phases could boost job creation and quality. A mix of interventions is required to tackle cost competitiveness, skills and attitudes.

title: A Model for Stable Governance in the 21st Century: The Meritocratic Diarchy
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: A Model for Stable Governance in the 21st Century: The Meritocratic Diarchy
detail.abstract: This paper outlines a novel model of governance, the Meritocratic Diarchy, designed to address the systemic issue of high time preference in modern democratic states-a phenomenon where short-term political incentives often lead to suboptimal long-term outcomes. The model synthesises the accountability and popular sovereignty of democracy with the stability and long-term perspective of a dedicated stewardship body. It proposes a dualistic structure: a democratically elected Legislative Administration for day-today governance, and an appointed Stewardship Council of non-political experts to safeguard the nation's long-term interests. After detailing the structure and its inherent challenge-a legitimacy crisis between democratic will and technocratic authority-the paper introduces a final integrating mechanism: a periodic, public performance review of Council members by a cross-party parliamentary committee. This paper argues that this complete model, while not without challenges, presents a resilient and adaptable framework for sustainable and prosperous governance.

title: An Adaptive Generative Adversarial Network for Multidimensional Anomaly Detection Using Lstm-Transformer Hybrid Model
affiliations: Guangdong University of Technology, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangdong University of Technology and Guangdong University of Technology

detail.title: An Adaptive Generative Adversarial Network for Multidimensional Anomaly Detection Using Lstm-Transformer Hybrid Model
detail.abstract: We propose a robust multivariate time series anomaly detection method. First, we design an adaptive dynamic weighted loss function that dynamically adjusts the loss weights by combining historical and current reconstruction errors, enabling the generator to focus more on high-confidence normal samples and mitigate the impact of anomaly contamination during training. Second, we introduce an adaptive threshold filtering mechanism, which assigns soft labels to reconstruction errors using a dynamic threshold and automatically filters out suspected anomalous samples before training the discriminator, thereby enhancing the discriminator’s ability to model the normal data distribution. Our method does not rely on a completely clean normal training set and can effectively model the distribution of normal data and detect anomalies even in the presence of contamination. Experimental results on multiple public datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms GAN methods in terms of both detection accuracy and robustness, highlighting its potential for application in complex real-world scenarios.
