title: Robust Multi-Objective Optimization in Home Energy Management Systems Using the Augmented Ε-Constraint
affiliations: Shahid Beheshti University and Shahid Beheshti University

detail.title: Robust Multi-Objective Optimization in Home Energy Management Systems Using the Augmented Ε-Constraint
detail.abstract: This work proposes a detailed framework of a home energy management system (HEMS) that incorporates vehicle-to-home (V2H) technology as an auxiliary power source, along with grid connectivity, photovoltaic (PV) generation, and battery energy storage (BES). The model also incorporates various household appliances, including controllable, thermostatically controlled, rigid-load, and uncontrollable devices.The proposed HEMS aims to minimize energy costs and peak-to-average ratio (PAR) and enhance thermal comfort. To effectively manage uncertainties specifically in real-time electricity pricing (RTP), the initial state of charge (SOC) of the plug-in electric vehicle (PEV), solar radiation, and ambient temperature, a robust optimization (RO) approach is adopted and integrated with the augmented ε-constraint (AUGMENCON) technique to address the multi-objective challenge. One of the main contributions of this research lies in integrating RO with AUGMENCON, where RO ensures solution resilience under worst-case uncertainty, and AUGMENCON effectively maps the Pareto front. The relative ideal distance (RID) index method is used to identify the most balanced trade-off point along the Pareto front. The outcomes of the simulations indicate that, even under worst-case scenarios,  the developed framework results in a 34.52% decrease in energy cost, a 7.5% reduction in PAR, and a 91.5% improvement in thermal comfort, highlighting the model's effectiveness in resilient and efficient home energy management.

title: Sustainable Consumption Under Constraints of Poverty and Income Inequality: Evidence from a Developing Country in the Asia-Pacific Region
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Sustainable Consumption Under Constraints of Poverty and Income Inequality: Evidence from a Developing Country in the Asia-Pacific Region
detail.abstract: Shifting consumption toward sustainability is key to balancing development and environmental goals. In small developing countries like Vietnam, rapid growth and inequality pose challenges for sustainable transitions. While many green consumer actions are promoted, their broader impacts remain unclear. This study introduces a framework to compare “green” interventions across three dimensions: carbon emission reduction, poverty alleviation, and income inequality. Applying it to Vietnam reveals trade-offs—interventions with higher emission reduction often worsen poverty and inequality. However, shifting household transport behavior stands out as a promising option, offering emission cuts with minimal negative social impacts and low sensitivity to rebound effects. In contrast, food-related changes show high potential but come with large uncertainties, highlighting the need for context-specific, equitable policies.

title: Improving Time Series Forecasting for Extrusion Process Monitoring Using a Hybrid Sarima & Random Forest Model
affiliations: University of New Haven, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of New Haven

detail.title: Improving Time Series Forecasting for Extrusion Process Monitoring Using a Hybrid Sarima & Random Forest Model
detail.abstract: Accurate forecasting of melt temperature and melt pressure is essential for maintaining product quality and operational efficiency in industrial polymer extrusion. We examine multiple time series approaches, including SARIMA, Random Forest (RF), and XGBoost, to forecast these process variables six-timesteps ahead. On one hand, SARIMA model reveals strong seasonality in melt temperature, while on the other, machine learning models, reproduce nonlinear dependencies, with RF outperforming SARIMA and XGBoost. Subsequently, a SARIMA+RF hybrid model is developed, combining statistical and machine learning techniques. This hybrid framework achieves the lowest forecasting errors, demonstrating its potential as a scalable and interpretable solution for real-time process monitoring.

title: Explaining Gender Gaps in Task Assignments and Performance at Private U.S. Law Firms
affiliations: Rutgers University - School of Management and Labor Relations, Princeton University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Explaining Gender Gaps in Task Assignments and Performance at Private U.S. Law Firms
detail.abstract: This paper explores potential explanations for the gaps in task assignments and performance between men and women associates in large U.S. law firms. We use a decomposition procedure that accounts for the importance of observed qualifications in hiring, work assignment, and performance assessment. Results show that the vast majority of the gender gaps in billable hours and the number of new clients remains unexplained by task assignment, mentorship, and pre-work characteristics, suggesting that traditionally important traits and activities have less impact than expected on the performance differential. Other factors such as networking, reduced bias, and institutional support appear to play a much larger role in improving the performance of legal associates. These results have implications for closing gender gaps in promotion and compensation in the law profession, given the importance of billable hours and new clients in determining salary and partnership opportunities.

title: Fiduciaries, Constituencies, and the Duty of Loyalty in Modern Nonprofits
affiliations: Northwestern law and Loyola Law School Los Angeles

detail.title: Fiduciaries, Constituencies, and the Duty of Loyalty in Modern Nonprofits
detail.abstract: A fiduciary of a charity has a fundamental duty to act in good faith and in a manner the fiduciary reasonably believes to be in the best interests of the charity in light of its purposes. In theory, this duty of loyalty seems uncomplicated and, in simple cases, it often is. In practice, for many fiduciaries discerning the content of the duty of loyalty, and sometimes even identifying the charity and the legal purposes to which the duty is owed, is not in fact so simple. Challenges to identifying and complying with fiduciary duties can arise when board members serve a charity because they reflect the experiences of certain constituencies or identities. Examples abound. University boards, for instance, have long included members who are students, union members, or other stakeholder representatives. Complications related to intersecting entities can also muddle understanding of a fiduciary's responsibilities. In this Article we offer a brief examination of the complications raised by various forms of constituency memberships, the ways in which fiduciary law attempts to clarify duties, and some tentative suggestions to ameliorate confusion regarding these duties.

title: Measuring Democracy Using the Wisdom of the Crowds
affiliations: University of Warwick and University of California, Davis

detail.title: Measuring Democracy Using the Wisdom of the Crowds
detail.abstract: Measuring democracy remains a core challenge in the social sciences. Leading indicators rely on the assessments of a small groups of experts. This paper identifies two key statistical limitations underlying these measurements. First, expert judgments are likely to be highly correlated, thus reducing the value of aggregation. Second, expert pools are often small and thus noisy. We model democracy as a latent, unobservable state and propose a new approach rooted in the logic of the "wisdom of crowds" to address these issues. We show that including a broader and more diverse set of observers - including non-experts - can improve inference. Our theoretical results quantify when such larger, decorrelated samples can outweigh the costs of noisier individual judgments, and thus provide more accurate estimates of the true state. We then develop an algorithm for implementation and apply it to data on democratic performance in the U.S., demonstrating significant empirical gains.

title: Upending the international order: Russia's war against Ukraine
affiliations: Old Dominion University - Graduate Program in International Studies

detail.title: Upending the international order: Russia's war against Ukraine
detail.abstract: Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022 shook the foundations of the current World Order. It exposed how fragile and fragmented international security, global economic structures, and old geopolitical alliances are under severe pressure from state actors in self-help security environment. This analysis looks at how the conflict started in 2014, tracing back the years of tension between Russia and NATO especially around Ukraine's desire to move closer to the West. The war has made it clear that international rules are only as strong as countries willing to follow them. It also demonstrates that global organizations like the UN often fall short in preventing these wars as Russia ignored widespread international condemnation and the Security Council was unable to act in due time to avert such crisis. The analysis digs into the far-reaching effects of the war-Western sanctions on Russia's economy but also pushed Russia to find new partners outside the Western sphere thereby making the world more divided. As new alliances are forming, some openly challenged democratic values creating more diverse opinions on the fundamental human right principles. All of these points to serious weaknesses in the security arrangements built after the Cold War, creating more conflicts amongst states. As countries find it difficult to cooperate in a delicate world order, instability and security dilemma often result from such a situation. Using ideas from realist thinkers such as Waltz and Morgenthau advocating power between states as a means of survival, critics of unchecked power like Bull and Mearsheimer often underline the need for cooperation in upholding a peaceful security environment. This study argues that the Ukrainian crisis is a major security test for the global security community, and it continues to divide global community in search for a common solution. Unless there are real changes to fix power imbalances between states and the flaws in international institutions, the current security atmosphere might be heading toward a fractured and chaotic world order. The paper calls for a fresh look at how peace can be maintained in a self-help security environment and opine cooperation as an inclusive policy in a world that's growing more complex and multipolar.

title: Financial Stability, Macroprudential Supervision and Early Warning Signals (EWS): A Minskyian Interpretation
affiliations: University Grenoble Alpes and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Financial Stability, Macroprudential Supervision and Early Warning Signals (EWS): A Minskyian Interpretation
detail.abstract: This article draws upon a Minskyian perspective about the stability issues of the financial system and considers the effectiveness of macroprudential policy through an analysis of the literature on early warning signals (EWS). Exploring current approaches to macroprudential policy, we find similarities with the financial instability hypothesis of Hyman Minsky that mainly relied on the endogenous nature of the crisis, the danger of excessive credit, and the financial stability paradox, developed long before the 2007-08 global financial crisis. Reviewing the set of academic papers investigating the effectiveness of EWS, we find that most of the indicators recognized in the research as effective are consistent with Minsky's approach since they bring forward the endogenous nature of instabilities. Moreover, it is obvious that one indicator cannot be considered as a universal predictor of crises. A set of indicators is required to allow an effective macroprudential policy. We propose an EWS framework where crisis is the result of the occurrence of financial vulnerability and trigger events. The resulting EWS framework is consistent with Minsky's approach and points to the endogenous nature of the evolution of credit to finance market expectations as the main vulnerability of financial stability.

title: Profitability in the banking sector and difference in exchange rate regimes: The cases of selected Sub-Saharan African countries
affiliations: FASEG

detail.title: Profitability in the banking sector and difference in exchange rate regimes: The cases of selected Sub-Saharan African countries
detail.abstract: This paper investigated whether profitability in banking sectors is sensitive to differences in exchange rate regimes in selected Sub-Saharan African countries: Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Gabon, Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius, Nigeria, Senegal, and South Africa. For, it compares the behaviors of specific production, structure, and efficiency variables along with macroeconomic variables as determinants of banks ROA, ROE, and interest spread in both fixed and flexible exchange rate regimes The model estimated using aggregated national banking data using panel regressions provided better results with banks interest spread as dependent variable. Globally, banks foreign liabilities, assets, and liabilities are weakly sensitive to differences in exchange rate regimes. Specifically, banks management quality is found significant for Ghana and South Africa while exchange rate is significant for Cameroon, Gabon, and Mauritius. This leads to a mixed result as exchange rate is not significant for Cote d'Ivoire and Senegal also fixed exchange rate countries. Banks assets are revealed significant determinants of their profitability for Ghana. Banks liabilities are found significant determinants for Cameroon Gabon, Mauritius, Nigeria, and South Africa.

title: A Systematic Review of Crypto Assets: Evolution, Opportunities, and Challenges
affiliations: Pannasastra University of Cambodia

detail.title: A Systematic Review of Crypto Assets: Evolution, Opportunities, and Challenges
detail.abstract: Crypto assets, encompassing cryptocurrencies, utility tokens, stablecoins, and non-fungible tokens, have significantly reshaped the financial landscape by introducing decentralized, blockchain-based mechanisms for value exchange. This paper presents a systematic literature review of 127 peer-reviewed sources published between 2010 and 2025, aimed at synthesizing current knowledge on the evolution, applications, and challenges of crypto assets. The review categorizes crypto assets based on their functions and technological foundations, highlighting their roles in decentralized finance (DeFi), tokenization of assets, and digital identity systems. Regulatory uncertainty, environmental concerns, and scalability limitations are identified as critical barriers to mainstream adoption. While interest and investment in crypto assets continue to grow, the study reveals substantial gaps in empirical research on their long-term economic impact and regulatory harmonization. The findings underscore the need for interdisciplinary collaboration to address these gaps and guide future innovations in this rapidly evolving domain.

title: Exploring SCO as a vehicle of Regional Economic Cooperation
affiliations: Independent and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Exploring SCO as a vehicle of Regional Economic Cooperation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The Authors have no personal or financial relationship with other people or organisations that may have or could be perceived to have influenced their study.
declarations.funderStatement: This was done under the banner of Roshni - a student led think tank, no funding was received for the report.

publicationDetails.detailsText: This has appeared only on Roshni's website.

detail.abstract:
This report explores the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) as a potential vehicle for
enhanced regional economic cooperation. While the SCO has established strong political and
security ties, economic integration among its member states remains limited. The report
analyses key areas such as trade, energy, infrastructure, tourism, and financial cooperation,
highlighting the structural and institutional gaps that hinder deeper economic collaboration.
It argues that trade remains uneven, with countries like Pakistan facing rising deficits due to
reliance on imports from larger economies. Energy cooperation holds significant promise,
given the region’s resource wealth, but remains underutilised. The report also emphasises the
need for improved cross-border connectivity, harmonised visa regimes, and joint tourism
initiatives to foster integration.
A central recommendation is the creation of an SCO Development Bank to finance
infrastructure and trade-related projects, promote financial transparency, and encourage local
currency use. The report concludes that while the SCO has foundational potential,
comprehensive reforms and coordinated policy frameworks are essential for it to function as
an effective regional economic bloc.

title: Greed and Fear in Investors: Dislocation via Financial Market Views
affiliations: Texas Tech University, Kean University, Texas Tech University, Texas Tech University and Johns Hopkins University - Carey Business School

detail.title: Greed and Fear in Investors: Dislocation via Financial Market Views
detail.abstract: This paper develops an integrated framework reconciling rational-expectations and behavioral finance by quantifying greed and fear in option markets. Using Cumulative Prospect Theory, we estimate probability-weighting functions for short-and long-dated options, capturing distortions between market-implied and spot-market beliefs. We document significant overweighting of downside risk at short horizons and underweighting of upside potential at long horizons, driving anomalies in the term structure and implied volatility skew. These insights provide a unified explanation for the equity premium puzzle by embedding behavioral distortions within a no-arbitrage asset-pricing model. We show that behavioral features can be systematically quantified to explain market dislocations in implied premiums. (JEL Codes G12, G13, G17 G41.)

title: Information, Pollution, and Cognition: The Impact of Air Pollution Disclosure on Aging Minds
affiliations: Beijing Normal University (BNU), University of International Business and Economics and Beijing Normal University (BNU) - School of Statistics

detail.title: Information, Pollution, and Cognition: The Impact of Air Pollution Disclosure on Aging Minds

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: Xin Zhang acknowledges financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (72473011) and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities.

detail.abstract: This study is among the first to examine the impact of a pollution information disclosure (PID) program on the cognitive abilities of middle-aged and elderly individuals in a developing country. Leveraging China's rollout of PID as a quasi-natural experiment and using nationally representative survey data, we find that the adoption of PID mitigates the adverse effect of PM2.5 exposure on cognitive performance by 53.01%. This effect is enhanced by increased awareness of pollution risks and changes in health-related behaviors. Moreover, the impact is more pronounced among men, younger cohorts, individuals with higher educational attainment, internet users, and those from higher-income households.

title: Financial markets stress indicator for Slovenia (FIMSIS) *
affiliations: Bank of Slovenia and Bank of Slovenia

detail.title: Financial markets stress indicator for Slovenia (FIMSIS) *
detail.abstract: The Global Financial Crisis (GFC) highlighted the importance of early identification of systemic financial stress and timely macroprudential policy responses. In this context, financial stress indices have become essential tools for monitoring systemic risk in real time. While composite indicators exist for the euro area and several member states, Slovenia has lacked such a measure, primarily due to limited financial market depth and data constraints. This paper introduces the Financial Markets Stress Indicator for Slovenia (FIMSIS), the first composite financial stress indicator developed specifically for the Slovenian financial system. FIMSIS aggregates volatility-based indicators across market segments using three alternative approaches-exponentially weighted moving average (EWMA), multivariate GARCH (BEKK) and principal component analysis (PCA)-allowing for a comparative evaluation of aggregation techniques. The indicator captures both the intensity and systemic dimension of financial stress and is evaluated through robustness checks and regime classification using a Markov-switching model. To assess predictive performance, we apply a Growth-at-Risk framework with Adaptive LASSO and non-crossing constraints. Results confirm FIMSIS's relevance for signalling downside macroeconomic risk.

title: Non-Financial Disclosure for Climate Investment: A Case for a Political-Industrial Ecology Approach Author
affiliations: Institute for Global Environmental Strategies

detail.title: Non-Financial Disclosure for Climate Investment: A Case for a Political-Industrial Ecology Approach Author
detail.abstract: The urgency of climate action is growing, yet significant barriers-such as a persistent global financing gap and weak governance structures-continue to hinder sustainability transitions, particularly in developing countries. Although there is increasing reliance on Non-Financial Disclosure (NFD) frameworks to guide climate investment, existing standards remain fragmented, poorly regulated, and are often overlooked in terms of equity and social inclusion. This paper investigates the methodologies for developing NFD product standards that align with the Paris Agreement and broader global sustainability goals. Based on a cross disciplinary narrative review, the paper synthesizes insights from environmental science, business studies, and social science to evaluate the effectiveness and limitations of dominant methodologies, including Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), Greenhouse Gas Emissions (GHGE), and Impact-Weighted Accounts (IWA). The prevailing NFD practices fail to adequately address the foundational principles of sustainable development-equity, inclusion, and the needs of socially and economically disadvantaged groups. The paper advocates for a political industrial-ecological (PIE) approach that integrates quantitative environmental tools with social science perspectives to address the shortcomings of current NFD systems. By bridging industrial ecology and political ecology, this framework can enhance the credibility, transparency, and fairness of NFD standards and better align them with both the goals of the Paris Agreement and social realities.

title: Macroeconomic Uncertainty and the Demand for Cash in Poland
affiliations: University of Economics in Katowice and University of Economics in Katowice

detail.title: Macroeconomic Uncertainty and the Demand for Cash in Poland

declarations.funderStatement: The research was co-financed by the Polish Ministry of Science grant ”Uncertainty: Measurement and Macroeconomic Effects” under the ”Regional Initiative of Excellence” programme.

detail.abstract: We examine the relationship between economic uncertainty and the demand for physical cash, setting our study apart from the extensive literature that focuses on broad monetary aggregates. We use two recently developed uncertainty indices for Poland-based on newspaper coverage and internet searches-spanning nearly 20 years, combined with autoregressive distributed lag (ARDL) models for long-run analysis and threshold regression for short-run investigation. We do not find a stable long-run relationship, but we observe significant nonlinearities in the short-run comovements. Large changes in uncertainty are associated with similar reactions in cash demand, while during "normal times", this relationship disappears or even reverses in some instances.

title: Rewarding Human-AI Collaboration: A Dynamic Theory of Managerial Compensation
affiliations: Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business

detail.title: Rewarding Human-AI Collaboration: A Dynamic Theory of Managerial Compensation
detail.abstract: We develop a dynamic principal-agent model to analyze optimal managerial incentives when Generative AI augments productivity. AI creates supermodular complementarities with human capital, fundamentally altering traditional contract design. Optimal contracts must balance performance incentives with explicit learning rewards to address externalities from AI skill development. High-skill managers receive stronger performance pay as AI advances-reversing standard risk-incentive trade-offs-while their learning investments amplify productivity advantages. This endogenous skill divergence drives rising within-firm wage inequality through multiple channels: direct productivity effects, learning amplification, and task-specific enhancements. We characterize optimal implementation paths that prioritize AI learning capabilities to maximize dynamic complementarities.

title: State Management in Serverless Workflows using Durable Functions on Azure
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: State Management in Serverless Workflows using Durable Functions on Azure
detail.abstract: This paper examines the integration of Azure Durable Functions with advanced state management techniques to address the challenges faced by serverless workflows, particularly in event-driven architectures. Serverless computing simplifies infrastructure management but struggles with maintaining state across distributed function executions. To overcome this, the paper proposes a hybrid state management framework that combines stateless function execution with externalized state stores, such as Redis and DynamoDB. The framework aims to ensure fault tolerance, scalability, and low-latency processing in long-running workflows. Through experimental validation, the paper demonstrates the potential of this framework in enhancing the efficiency and reliability of cloud-native applications. The study also explores the practical implications of this solution for industries such as healthcare and finance, highlighting its importance in the context of modern event-driven and cloud computing systems.

reference: Edited volume: Global Gig Economy and the Local Conditioning of Algorithmic Work. Illinois Press
title: Riders of the Storm: The Rise of Snapp! and Workers Struggle in Iran
affiliations: State University of New York (SUNY) - Stony Brook, Students

detail.title: Riders of the Storm: The Rise of Snapp! and Workers Struggle in Iran

publicationDetails.detailsText: Edited volume: Global Gig Economy and the Local Conditioning of Algorithmic Work. Illinois Press

detail.abstract: This chapter investigates how Iran’s leading ride-hailing platform, Snapp!, exemplifies the intersection of platform capitalism, authoritarian labor governance, and international sanctions. Drawing on secondary sources, policy documents, platform regulations, and labor protests, it examines how the Iranian state actively promotes digital platforms as a strategy to absorb surplus labor and mitigate unemployment amidst economic crisis. Unlike gig platforms operating in liberal economies, Snapp! is embedded in a state-controlled and militarized economy, benefiting from regulatory privileges, foreign capital channeled through parastatal entities, and impunity from labor oversight. The chapter shows how Snapp! enforces labor discipline through a combination of algorithmic management, formal legal penalties, and ethnic segmentation, enabling unprecedented levels of wage suppression and worker control. Workers classified as “driver users” are excluded from legal protections and subjected to opaque performance-based sanctions, while surveillance technologies and political repression preempt collective organizing. Despite these constraints, Snapp! drivers have staged strikes, digital campaigns, and protest actions, demonstrating the persistent agency of precarious workers under authoritarian conditions. However, the state-platform alliance has systematically suppressed these efforts through digital retaliation and legal threats. The chapter argues that Snapp! institutionalizes a uniquely repressive model of gig labor in which digital innovation serves not as a vehicle of economic empowerment, but as a mechanism of labor containment. By foregrounding Iran’s case, the chapter challenges dominant global narratives that frame platform labor primarily through deregulation, revealing how authoritarian states repurpose digital capitalism to deepen labor precarity and political control.

title: Efficient Monte Carlo estimation of credit concentration risk
affiliations: UCLouvain - LFIN/LIDAM and LFIN/LIDAM, UCLouvain

detail.title: Efficient Monte Carlo estimation of credit concentration risk

declarations.funderStatement: The work of Frédéric Vrins is supported by the Fonds de la Recherche Scientifique - (F.S.R.-FNRS) grant CDR J.0225.24. Computational resources have been provided by the supercomputing facilities of the Université catholique de Louvain (CISM/UCL) and the Consortium des Équipements de Calcul Intensif en Fédération Wallonie Bruxelles (CECI) funded by the F.R.S.-FNRS under convention 2.5020.11 and by the Walloon Region.

detail.abstract: In this paper we address the explicit exclusion of credit concentration risk from the Pillar 1 minimum capital requirements formulas of the Basel framework. Leveraging on a well established Gaussian multi-factor model, we introduce a novel control variate estimator of value-at-risk (VaR), suitable for measuring sector concentration risk under the Pillar 2 guidelines. This estimator integrates the precision of Monte Carlo simulations with the speed and simplicity of the Large Pool approximation, aiming for a more efficient quantile estimation tool. We conduct numerical experiments in a two systematic factor setup to test the validity of our methodology, achieving consistent variance reduction compared to the benchmark Monte Carlo estimator. Our results are robust across various pool parameters and increasing number of Monte Carlo simulations.

title: Can Simple Models Predict Football — and Beat the Odds? Lessons from the German Bundesliga
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Can Simple Models Predict Football — and Beat the Odds? Lessons from the German Bundesliga
detail.abstract: This study examines whether a simple model based on expected goals (xG) can generate accurate forecasts and identify profitable signals in football betting markets. The model uses recent xG to estimate win-draw-loss probabilities via a Skellam distribution, with isotonic regression applied for calibration, and evaluates the performance over eleven Bundesliga seasons (2014/15 through 2024/25). While bookmaker odds tend to exhibit superior statistical calibration, the xG-based model captures certain signals not fully reflected in market prices. In simulated betting, the model yields a return on investment of approximately 10% using average market odds, increasing to nearly 15% under the best available prices. Profits stem predominantly from home win bets, while backing away wins is consistently loss-making. The results show some robustness to modelling choices, though profitability varies considerably by season and bet type. The study highlights the potential of simple models as practical tools for identifying predictive value in structured football data.

title: Utilizing Grpc For High-Performance Inter-Service Communication In .NET
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: Utilizing Grpc For High-Performance Inter-Service Communication In .NET
detail.abstract: In modern cloud-native architectures, particularly microservices-based systems, effective interservice communication (IPC) is essential for ensuring system performance, scalability, and reliability. Among the various communication protocols available, gRPC has emerged as a promising solution due to its low-latency and high-throughput characteristics. This paper investigates the use of gRPC for high-performance IPC in .NET-based microservices architectures. By comparing gRPC with REST API and RabbitMQ, we evaluate its performance under varying load conditions, focusing on throughput, latency, and availability. The results highlight that gRPC outperforms REST API in scenarios requiring low latency and high throughput, while RabbitMQ provides better scalability in asynchronous communication models. Despite the performance benefits, gRPC introduces complexities in its implementation and development, particularly due to its reliance on Protocol Buffers. The paper concludes that gRPC is a highly suitable option for microservices requiring fast and reliable communication, with recommendations for future research into its integration with other systems and message brokers.

title: Break a peg! A study of stablecoin co-instability
affiliations: International University of Monaco (IUM) and International University of Monaco (IUM)

detail.title: Break a peg! A study of stablecoin co-instability
detail.abstract: Following the increasing adoption of stablecoins, their robustness has become an ongoing concern for investors and regulators alike. This article studies the co-instability of a large panel of stablecoins by identifying their structural breaks and co-occurrences. Moreover, we use Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) and Dynamic Conditional Correlation DCC-GARCH models to assess spillover effects in the wake of four major black swan events in the crypto world. Similar to prior literature, we conclude that algorithmic stablecoins were the major shock receivers of the IRON TITAN and TERRA LUNA crashes, highlighting the importance of allowing for sufficient margins of safety in their design. We also observe that the FTX bankruptcy and the Silicon Valley Bank collapse had repercussions of a different nature and affected more categories of stablecoins, from algorithmic to fiat money-backed. We also highlight how, irrespective of the idiosyncratic or systemic nature of the shocks, wellknown custodial stablecoins, as well as the most successful crypto-collateralized tokens, showed resilience during or in the immediate aftermath of these events.

title: Assessing the impact of natural land on farmland value in Mediterranean EU countries
affiliations: Università degli Studi di Catania and Yale University - School of Forestry & Environmental Studies

detail.title: Assessing the impact of natural land on farmland value in Mediterranean EU countries
detail.abstract: Despite the increasing recognition of ecosystem services in agricultural landscapes, empirical evidence on the economic value of specific natural land cover types in agriculture remains limited. We address this gap in the literature applying an hedonic approach to evaluate the contribution of specific forests, shrubs, grassland, and wetlands to farmland value. Using farmlevel data and landscape-level land cover information, we assess the impact of natural land cover types on farmland value across five Euro-Mediterranean countries considering farms specializing in crops and livestock. Our research extends previous studies by offering a more comprehensive economic analysis that incorporates multiple ecosystem types and applies a novel approach, the relative shift method, to account for the compositional nature of land use data. Our findings contribute to the land-sharing versus land-sparing debate. We find that all natural land classes have a positive impact on farmland value for the whole sample, thus supporting the land-sharing approach. However, when focusing exclusively on crop farms, peat bogs exhibit a negative impact on farmland value, suggesting that a land-sparing strategy may be more appropriate in such contexts. In addition we found substantial differences across farm types when assessing the impact of policy reallocating land from agriculture to natural cover, underscoring the need for targeted land management strategies.

title: Development and Transformation of the Balanced Scorecard Concept
affiliations: Trakia University and Kaneff University Hospital

detail.title: Development and Transformation of the Balanced Scorecard Concept

declarations.declarationOfInterest: not applicable
declarations.ethicsApproval: not applicable
declarations.funderStatement: not applicable

detail.abstract: The article examines the evolution of the Balanced Scorecard (BSC)-from a tool for measuring organizational performance to an integrated framework for strategic management and control. It analyzes the limitations of traditional financial control, which fails to account for intangible assets, innovation, and long-term goals. The main stages in the development of the BSC are outlined, including its transition to a third-generation model that incorporates measurement, feedback, communication, and active management involvement. The article emphasizes the role of the BSC as a key managerial tool in today's knowledge-based and sustainabilityoriented economy.

title: Economic Implications of MAHA-Inspired School Meal Priorities
affiliations: The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Purdue University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Case Western Reserve University

detail.title: Economic Implications of MAHA-Inspired School Meal Priorities
detail.abstract: The Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) campaign has brought a renewed focus on children's health and nutrition to the national stage and an onslaught of both approved and proposed statelevel regulations that mandate changes to school meals. The U.S. school nutrition programs, which operate in over 90,000 schools and serve free or reduced-price meals to nearly 30 million students each day, operate on tight margins. Here, we assess the implications for several MAHA school meal priorities (removing criticized ingredients, restricting the use of ultra-processed foods, increasing scratch cooking, and increasing local, organic, or regenerative food procurement) on the costs and revenues of school nutrition programs. For each change, we highlight likely sources of heterogeneity in compliance, revenues, and cost across school types, including the age, size, and locations of schools. Additionally, we aim to contextualize each change by summarizing past related efforts and challenges. The results are likely to be useful for stakeholders including both state and federal policymakers currently debating and passing school meal legislation, schools working to anticipate or comply with changes, and others. Additionally, while the both the program structure and the MAHA campaign are unique to the U.S., the challenge of balancing nutrition, taste, and cost in school nutrition programs and the debate about ingredients, ultra processed foods, and procurement are common across many countries.

title: Boosting Retirement Income through Dynamic Withdrawals
affiliations: Samasthiti Advisors

detail.title: Boosting Retirement Income through Dynamic Withdrawals
detail.abstract:
Dynamic withdrawal strategies, extensively researched internationally, remain underexplored in India. This paper bridges this significant research gap by rigorously evaluating popular dynamic withdrawal methods using Indian data. Employing simulations based on historical equity, debt and inflation data from the Indian market, we compare 10 different adaptive and dynamic withdrawal strategies. The study demonstrates that dynamic strategies can improve withdrawals and sustainability compared to static withdrawal methods. However, this improvement comes at a significant cost of volatility in receiving income from a retirement portfolio.

We use multiple metrics to evaluate dynamic withdrawal strategies across four broad areas: ability to support recurring expenditure (spending), possibility of leaving an inheritance (savings), volatility in income generation (stability) and the ability of the corpus to last the full retirement period (sustainability). The study then introduces the RetireAbility Index which combines these different metrics to arrive at a composite score for each withdrawal strategy, enabling retirees and advisors to pick a strategy best suited for their needs.

title: Monetary Policy Exposure of Banks and Loan Contracting
affiliations: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and University of Missouri at Columbia

detail.title: Monetary Policy Exposure of Banks and Loan Contracting
detail.abstract: We provide evidence that banks use loan covenants to prepare for future contractionary monetary policy, thereby facilitating the bank lending channel of monetary policy transmission. Specifically, we show that banks with greater monetary policy exposure–banks whose lending capacity contracts more as the federal funds rate increases–include stricter covenants in loan contracts, which give them flexibility to reduce lending during monetary policy tightening when firms breach a covenant. Our findings highlight the role of covenants in the transmission of monetary policy and imply that even firms with long-term loans remain exposed to credit contractions resulting from monetary policy tightening.

title: Social Aspects of Food Security
affiliations: Trakia University, Trakia University and Kaneff University Hospital

detail.title: Social Aspects of Food Security

declarations.declarationOfInterest: not applicable
declarations.ethicsApproval: not applicable
declarations.funderStatement: not applicable

detail.abstract: Social security protects the vital interests of society, the individual, and the family from external and internal threats. This is of particular interest from a scientific research point of view. All the main elements of the social system, which ensure the level and quality of life of the population and are regulated by social and national policy, have been studied. The criteria with the help of which the state and level of social security can be studied have been analyzed. The need to develop strategic plans for the development of agriculture for each country has been proven, which is based on the understanding that there are no "universal" solutions for each country.

title: Planning with Complanai: Comparative Insights from a Human–Ai Evaluation of Comprehensive Plans
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Seoul National University and Seoul National University

detail.title: Planning with Complanai: Comparative Insights from a Human–Ai Evaluation of Comprehensive Plans
detail.abstract: This study examines the application of ComPlanAI—a hybrid AI tool combining rule-based computation and large language models (LLMs)—in comprehensive urban planning. Using a Turing Test-based comparison in Incheon, South Korea, we assessed an AI-generated plan and a human-generated counterpart through expert evaluations (n=86). The AI-generated plan exhibited strengths in data integration, alignment with upper-level strategies, and operational guidance. In contrast, the human-authored plan was superior in narrative clarity and contextual framing. These results highlight a cognitive complementarity between human planners and AI systems, suggesting that hybrid collaboration can improve consistency, interdepartmental coordination, and decision-making. The study offers empirical insight into how generative AI can support the co-production of planning strategies in institutional contexts, particularly in resource-constrained municipalities.

title: Discrimination in Access to Corporate Insiders: Evidence from a Pre-Registered Field Experiment
affiliations: University of Colorado at Boulder, Indiana University - Kelley School of Business, Indiana University - Kelley School of Business and Indiana University - Kelley School of Business

detail.title: Discrimination in Access to Corporate Insiders: Evidence from a Pre-Registered Field Experiment

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This research received IRB approval from the authors’ respective institutions.

detail.abstract: We examine whether investor characteristics create barriers to accessing corporate insiders-an important information channel in financial markets. Using a pre-registered 2×2×2 field experiment, we send meeting requests from fictious investors to 2,731 U.S. public companies, systematically manipulating investor race (Black and White), gender (female and male), and type (retail and professional). We find evidence of racial discrimination: White investors receive meeting approvals 34% more often than Black investors. This disparity persists across investor types, suggesting taste-based rather than statistical discrimination. Gender discrimination manifests differently-we find no statistically significant differences in initial meeting access, but conditional on securing meetings, female investors are 62% less likely to be offered a meeting with C-suite executives. Investor type alone does not affect meeting access, challenging assumptions about the differential treatment of retail investors versus professional investors. These findings reveal that informal barriers to information access vary systematically by investor characteristics, advancing our understanding of discrimination in financial markets and providing insight into the landscape of corporate information access.

title: Toward an Intelligent Economic Agent: Integrating DSGE Models, Causal Graphs, and Natural Language by

detail.title: Toward an Intelligent Economic Agent: Integrating DSGE Models, Causal Graphs, and Natural Language by
detail.abstract: This paper introduces Carmen, the AI Economist, an innovative AI-driven framework designed to integrate structural economic models, causal inference, and natural language reasoning into a single system for real-time, explainable macroeconomic analysis. Existing economic forecasting tools often lack the ability to provide transparent, counterfactual reasoning that is essential for policy evaluation and decision support. Meanwhile, current AI systems typically lack grounding in formal economic theory, limiting their applicability for rigorous economic insights. Carmen proposes a novel architecture that combines lightweight DSGE model modules with a causal graph engine and a natural language interface, enabling interactive exploration of complex economic scenarios-from global macroeconomic trends to industry and region/local-specific analysis forecasts. The system aims to support policymakers, researchers, and industry stakeholders by delivering model-consistent explanations and dynamic scenario analysis.

title: The Impact of Perceived Dimensions of Sustainability on Life Satisfaction and Citizen Civic Engagement in Developing Countries

detail.title: The Impact of Perceived Dimensions of Sustainability on Life Satisfaction and Citizen Civic Engagement in Developing Countries
detail.abstract: The research evaluates the influence of citizens' perceptions of the attributes and respective significant dimensions of Sustainability in cities, as defined in the SDGs and NBR ISO 37120:2017, on civic engagement. The research has a quantitative and descriptive approach using Structural Equation Modelling statistics, starting with a survey of citizens from two cities in the South Brazilian region. The study applies the Citylifesat scale to understand and evaluate the impacts on life satisfaction and civic engagement in the context of sustainable cities. The study showed the validity of civic engagement in the context of sustainable cities, and its results showed that citizens' civic engagement has a significant positive direct and indirect impact on safety and place attachment dimensions. Health and well-being dimension in cities received a significant positive impact of the recreation, safety, and primary services dimensions. Beside this, health and well-being point out a significant negative impact on civic engagement. This study highlights the importance of citizen perceptions for sustainable urban development and civic engagement and helps prioritize sustainable development in cities and it enhances comprehension of citizen civic engagement in sustainable cities. The research supports public and private managers in defining effective strategies for sustainability. By identifying citizens' perceptions of sustainability dimensions, decision-making is guided, and sustainable strategies are created to meet present and future population needs.

title: Did Household Consumption Expenditure Improve During Covid-19 in Nigeria: An Overview of Pre and Post Era

detail.title: Did Household Consumption Expenditure Improve During Covid-19 in Nigeria: An Overview of Pre and Post Era
detail.abstract: This study reviews the effect of covid-19 on household consumption expenditure during pre and post covid-19 era. In order to examine if household consumption expenditure improved or not, we examined measures such as household consumption expenditure, purchasing power parity (PPP), foreign remittances, household disposable income, and household consumer confidence was assessed from 2015 to 2021 and the findings shows that covid-19 contributed to fall in Nigerian household consumption expenditure. We captured the growth in consumption in real and nominal terms, consumptions made by households, government, individual and non-profit institutions serving households (NPISH) was assessed and it was discovered that growth on consumption occurred in the aforesaid economic agents. Again, the well-being of the households examined using poverty headcounts, level of happiness, hunger index, and prosperity index and it was discovered that due to outbreak of covid-19 pandemic in Nigeria, the rate of poverty headcounts increased during and post covid-19 era was high; the level of happiness diminished and rate of hunger increased. Policies such are government improvement of agricultural sector and economic diversification was suggested since the study concludes that covid-19 pandemic have great negative impact in household consumption expenditure.

detail.abstract: The research focuses on the intellectual property developments made by the member states of the GCC and how intellectual property development and subsequent deployment, can act as a catalyst for financial prosperity. The main purpose of the research is to analyse and examine the intellectual property provisions currently in existence within the states of the GCC. The aim is to provide recommendations to improve the current level of intellectual property protection at both a national level and at a state level in the GCC through an integrated intellectual property protection model. There have been three main stages in the development of intellectual property in the Gulf states; a pre Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) stage, the current level of TRIPS compliance and a push towards TRIPS Plus. To date, each individual Gulf state has developed its intellectual property laws at varying rates. Post 2000, the Gulf states all display a set of intellectual property laws that are largely compliant with TRIPS. Therefore a question arises as to how much scope there is in the current laws to accede to more stringent intellectual property provisions. The research will show this is a key question for the GCC, its international partners and the wider trading communities of the WTO. The findings of the research are that the GCC does not have the capacity to take on TRIPS Plus provisions without compromising its sharia laws and value and that instead an integrated intellectual property protection model is needed.

title: Digital Infrastructure and AI-Driven FDI: An Econometric Analysis of India and China (2000-2023)

detail.title: Digital Infrastructure and AI-Driven FDI: An Econometric Analysis of India and China (2000-2023)
detail.abstract: In this paper, we explore the impact of digital infrastructure on AI-driven foreign direct investment (FDI) flows in emerging economies, focusing on India and China in the context of rapid technological change and evolving geopolitical dynamics. To examine the key determinants of FDI, the study uses balanced panel data covering a 24-year period (2000-2023). Our model includes a composite digital infrastructure index, gross domestic product (GDP), AI policy dummies, and a geopolitical shift variable to evaluate the differential investment patterns across both countries. The results indicate a significant positive relationship between digital infrastructure and AI-driven FDI, with policy timing and global political context influencing divergent investment trajectories in India and China. These findings underscore the strategic role of digital infrastructure in attracting high-value foreign investment and offer relevant implications for national AI strategies and development policy in emerging economies.

detail.abstract: This study explores the impact of stock market development on economic growth in Nepal, covering data from 1994 to 2022. Using the Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ARDL) approach, the analysis confirms a significant long-term relationship between key stock market variables-particularly paid-up capital and the number of listed companies-and Gross Domestic Product (GDP). These findings highlight the crucial role of capital accumulation and market expansion in promoting sustained economic growth. In contrast, variables such as market capitalization, turnover, and government education expenditure showed limited or no significant influence on Nepal's economic growth in the long run. The short-run analysis revealed that real market capitalization has a significant but negative effect on GDP, while turnover was insignificant, indicating that short-term market fluctuations may not directly support economic development. Diagnostic tests confirmed the robustness and stability of the econometric model, while Granger causality tests indicated both bidirectional and unidirectional causal relationships between stock market indicators and economic growth. Based on these findings, the study recommends policy interventions focused on strengthening capital formation, promoting market listings and investor participation, improving market efficiency and investor protection, integrating financial and human capital development, and enhancing financial infrastructure and institutional frameworks. By implementing these policies, Nepal can better harness its stock market as a driver of inclusive and sustainable economic growth.

title: Decomposed Multi-Scale Temporal-Channel Interaction with Bidirectional Mamba for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
affiliations: Shanghai University, Shanghai University, Hebei Normal University, Shanghai University, Zhengzhou University and Shanghai University

detail.title: Decomposed Multi-Scale Temporal-Channel Interaction with Bidirectional Mamba for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
detail.abstract: Multivariate long-term time series forecasting is essential in various real-world applications, including energy consumption, traffic flow, and environmental monitoring. Nonetheless, modeling intricate temporal relationships and scale-aware dynamics across long horizons remains inherently difficult. Existing methods often struggle to balance temporal patterns with computational efficiency. Two major challenges remain: First, Transformer-based models, while effective in modeling long-range dependencies, suffer from quadratic complexity, hindering their scalability to ultra-long sequences. Second, existing multi-scale architectures often process different temporal resolutions independently, neglecting high-order interactions between coarse and fine-grained features. To address these issues, we propose DMTI-BiMamba, a novel forecasting framework that proposes a Decomposed Multi-scale Temporal-channel Interaction with Bidirectional Mamba. Specifically, the input sequence is decomposed into structural evolutions and periodic patterns. A multi-scale architecture Temporal-channel Interaction module is applied to the structural evolution component to extract hierarchical temporal dependencies at different resolutions. At the same time, an innovative bidirectional Mamba module captures long-range dynamics in both forward and backwards directions to reduce cumulative error for periodic pattern components. This model ensures both computational efficiency and modeling expressiveness. Extensive experiments on eight public datasets across multiple forecasting horizons demonstrate that DMTI-BiMamba achieves state-of-the-art performance in both accuracy and robustness, outperforming existing baselines, including Transformer-based, linear models, and graph-based methods.

title: Inducing Activation Map Sparsity and Conducting Dual Sparse Training with Transformed $\Ell1$ Regularization
affiliations: Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University, Xidian University and Xidian University

detail.title: Inducing Activation Map Sparsity and Conducting Dual Sparse Training with Transformed $\Ell1$ Regularization
detail.abstract: Although deep neural networks continue to advance rapidly, their substantial computational and memory demands still pose challenges for deployment on low-power devices. To address these challenges, extensive efforts have been devoted to neural network pruning, activation sparsity induction, and specialized hardware accelerators. Among them, regularization-based activation sparsity induction is a promising yet underexplored direction. Existing methods often exhibit limited sparsity gains, poor sparsity–accuracy trade-off, and weak generalization. These limitations largely stem from the lack of systematic analysis in the introduction of regularizers. In this work, we first conduct an empirical analysis to identify the key properties of effective activation sparsity regularizers—namely, the ability to suppress small activations while preserving distribution continuity. Guided by these insights, we propose to introduce Transformed ℓ1 (Tℓ1) as a principled regularizer for inducing activation sparsity. Further, we propose a dual sparse training pipeline that integrates traditional pruning and activation sparsity induction in a three-stage design. The pipeline jointly enhances static sparsity in weights and dynamic sparsity in activations, thereby improving inference efficiency. Extensive experiments across multiple models and datasets show that Tℓ1 improves activation sparsity by over 20% without sacrificing accuracy. Specifically, it improves sparsity by 27.52% on ResNet-18 (ImageNet-1K) and 44.04% on LeNet-5 (MNIST). In addition, the proposed pipeline reduces floating-point operations by 81.70% on ResNet-18 and 84.13% on ResNet-50. A case study on Flexagon, an accelerator supporting sparse–sparse matrix multiplication, demonstrates that the dual sparse model achieves up to 1.46x lower inference latency under identical weight sparsity levels.

title: Strategic Uncertainty in Collective Action Problems12
affiliations: Universidad Loyola Andalucia, University College London - Department of Economics, University of the Basque Country and Universidad Loyola Andalucía

detail.title: Strategic Uncertainty in Collective Action Problems12
detail.abstract: Collective action problems typically involve two types of uncertainty: uncertainty about the parameters or structure of the problem itself, and uncertainty stemming from the unpredictability of other agents’ behavior (strategic uncertainty). To isolate their effects, we experimentally manipulate ambiguity levels in the problem’s design and elicit participants’ beliefs about others’ contributions in a public good game, using a representative sample (n = 1,500) of the Spanish population. Participants decide how much to contribute to a public good game and predict group members’ contributions. Our results highlight the decisive role of strategic uncertainty: individuals who perceive greater dispersion in peers’ contributions tend to cooperate more, though this relation weakens at higher expected contributions. Conversely, ambiguity (regarding the game’s parameters) has no significant impact on contributions or beliefs. Thus, our findings suggest that the fragility of collective action arises primarily from uncertainty regarding others’ behavior, rather than from inherent uncertainties in the nature of the problem itself.

title: Should We Mind the Gap? An Assessment of the Benefits of Equity Markets and Policy Implications for Europe's Capital Markets Union
affiliations: European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB), European Central Bank (ECB), Goethe University Frankfurt - House of Finance and European Central Bank (ECB)

detail.title: Should We Mind the Gap? An Assessment of the Benefits of Equity Markets and Policy Implications for Europe's Capital Markets Union
detail.abstract: The European Union (EU) economy depends heavily on bank funding. For this reason, strengthening EU equity markets as an alternative funding source has been a policy priority under the Capital Markets Union (CMU) agenda, and more recently a key feature of the Savings and Investment Union (SIU). EU listed equity markets are smaller and structurally different from those in the United States (US), with differing market capitalisations of listed firms and differences in the number of companies listed, stemming from lower initial public offering (IPO) activity in Europe. This paper aims to understand the drivers behind the EU-US listing gap, focusing on two aspects: (1) the general firm-level benefits of listing, and (2) whether pre-listing financing opportunities in the EU are underdeveloped, hindering firm growth and ultimately market depth. This paper first puts forward an empirical analysis to assess how a firm’s decision to list impacts various key performance indicators, with a view to assessing the implications of listing for the economy at large. Second, it zooms in on innovative firms to shed light on the primary challenges faced by EU startups in their funding pipelines, with a focus on late-stage equity financing and venture capital (VC) markets. Focusing on the euro area (EA) as a proxy to derive broader benefits of listing in the EU, we find that EA companies’ key profitability measures, employment, innovation capacity and productivity all increase after listing – and are thus indicative of wider economic benefits. This is, however, associated with challenges for the long-term investment strategies of listed companies, such as potential short-termism – a topic widely studied in the literature. Moreover, a comparison with the US suggests that, while the benefits and risks of listing are qualitatively similar on the other side of the Atlantic, EA companies seem to benefit somewhat less from listing than their US peers. title: Subnational Inflation Dynamics and Anchoring Mechanisms: Empirical Evidence from Regional Spillovers in Peru
affiliations: Pontificia Universidad Católica de Perú and Universidad del Pacifico

detail.title: Subnational Inflation Dynamics and Anchoring Mechanisms: Empirical Evidence from Regional Spillovers in Peru
detail.abstract: This study investigates Lima's suitability as Peru's inflation-targeting anchor by analyzing regional spillovers across nine economic regions using monthly CPI data (2002-2024). Employing both Diebold-Yilmaz time-domain and Baruník-Křehlík frequency-domain frameworks, we quantify the direction, magnitude, and persistence of inflation transmission. Results reveal strong regional interdependence (73.60% total spillover index) with Lima as the dominant net transmitter (23.94 percentage points). However, frequency decomposition uncovers striking cyclical heterogeneity: Lima receives short-run shocks from food-producing regions but dominates long-run transmission (44.70% vs. 28.99% frequency spillover index). Rolling-window analysis during COVID-19 shows temporary spillover disruption (connectivity declining from 75% to 68%) followed by recovery during 2022's inflationary surge. Robustness checks across specifications, granular city-level data, and three-band frequency segmentation confirm Lima's structural centrality at lower frequencies. These findings validate the Central Reserve Bank's Lima-centered approach for long-run targeting while revealing asymmetric frequency-dependent spillovers. The presence of short-run regional shocks suggests integrating upstream agricultural signals could enhance near-term forecasting and policy responsiveness.

title: Revisiting the Housing Channel of Monetary Policy: A Narrative Sign Restriction Approach
affiliations: Emory University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Revisiting the Housing Channel of Monetary Policy: A Narrative Sign Restriction Approach
detail.abstract: This paper explores whether monetary policy transmission through housing markets exhibits structural variation across different economic regimes, examining two critical periods: the Global Financial Crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic. Using a ninevariable SVAR augmented with narrative sign restrictions for the 1985-2023 period, we investigate whether the housing-output trade-off in monetary policy remains stable across conventional and unconventional policy environments. We find that while the magnitude of monetary policy effects varies substantially across regimes, a fundamental relationship persists: house prices respond approximately three to four times more than output to monetary shocks. During the GFC, both effects amplify proportionally, while COVID-19 weakens transmission channels without improving the trade-off ratio. Identification of house price shocks reveals that central banks already respond endogenously to housing developments, yet unfavorable trade-offs remain. These findings demonstrate that the constraint on using monetary policy for housing market stabilization represents a structural feature that transcends specific economic conditions.

title: The Productivity Effects of Artificial Intelligence: A Comparative Analysis of a New General-Purpose Technology and its Transfer

detail.title: The Productivity Effects of Artificial Intelligence: A Comparative Analysis of a New General-Purpose Technology and its Transfer
detail.abstract: Purpose: This study synthesizes and evaluates the empirical evidence on the transfer and diffusion of artificial intelligence (AI) by analyzing whether its implementation delivers productivity gains that consistently exceed those of previous general-purpose technologies (GPTs), such as information and communication technology (ICT) and electricity. It aims to clarify the magnitude, mechanisms, and contextual dependencies of AI's impact, framing the issue as a challenge in technology transfer from development to widespread economic application. Methodology: A systematic literature review was conducted following the PRISMA 2020 framework. The search utilized the Consensus academic search engine, covering sources like Semantic Scholar and PubMed, with 22 targeted queries across seven thematic groups. The process involved identifying 1,100 papers, screening 630, assessing 491 for eligibility, and conducting a full-text analysis and narrative synthesis of the 50 most relevant studies. Methodologies of the included papers range from large-scale panel data regressions and randomized controlled trials to systematic reviews and macroeconomic analyses.

title: Reducing the Burden of Diseases Through Innovation: An Old Question Revisited
affiliations: Sharif University of Technology, Sharif University of Technology and Sheffield University Management School

detail.title: Reducing the Burden of Diseases Through Innovation: An Old Question Revisited
detail.abstract: In the rapidly changing world of today, healthcare is no exception in being constantly impacted by innovations and technological changes. Central to academic inquiries in healthcare has been the question of to what extent have innovations been effective in improving indicators of health in a society. In this article, we reevaluate the relationship between innovation and one specific measure of health, namely the burden of disease, in both high-income as well as middle and low-income countries. In doing so, we hypothesize and find an association between health-related patents and publications on one hand, and disability adjusted life years (DALYs), on the other. Using a panel data model on a sample of 70 countries from 2000 to 2019, we found that health-related publications significantly contribute to the reduction of disease burden across both OECD members and other countries. However, in non-OECD countries we found no significant relationship between health-related patents and disease burden, which could be due to weaker Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) protection or a limited capability of the healthcare system to capture value from innovations. We also find no association between health innovations and the reduction of disease burden in adults, despite a significant association in other age groups.

detail.abstract: This paper extends the reference class forecasting model to univariate time series forecasting. It provides a comprehensive discussion on the algorithms for selecting Reference Class (RC) for two types of time series data: those with a constant mean and those with a time-varying mean. This paper introduces two forecasting techniques-mean-based forecasting and regression-based forecasting within the reference class framework along with forecasting intervals. The Reference Class Time Series Forecasting (RCTF) technique generally outperforms the ARIMA (p, d, q) models. The experiment results suggest about 96.3 % and 98.59 % accuracy of RCTFs for mean and regression based forecast respectively, while 92.83 % for ARIMA (p, q, d) models for the same set of time series.

We provide a novel rationale—centered on how PPCs affect platforms’ incentives to acquire data—for why a complete ban on PPCs may harm sellers.

title: Investigation of the Evolution of Groundwater–Soil–Vegetation Systems in Semi-Arid Regions Using Coupled Pca-Apcs-Mlr and Ewm Models

detail.title: Investigation of the Evolution of Groundwater–Soil–Vegetation Systems in Semi-Arid Regions Using Coupled Pca-Apcs-Mlr and Ewm Models
detail.abstract: Coal mining activities in semi-arid regions can significantly disrupt groundwater systems, leading to a range of ecological and environmental issues, including water quality degradation, soil contamination, and vegetation loss. However, current studies on the evolution of groundwater–soil–vegetation ecosystems in mining areas often overlook or overly simplify the complex nonlinear interactions among these components. This study takes the Bojianghaizi Basin in China as a case, using remote sensing inversion, hydrogeological surveys, soil habitat assessments, PCA-APCS-MLR, EWM, OLS models, and hydrogeochemical methods to compare groundwater-soil-vegetation system evolution under coal mining and natural conditions. The results reveal that groundwater in coal mining areas is mainly Cl·SO₄-Na type, while natural areas are dominated by HCO₃-Ca type. Mining activities enhance the dissolution of calcium-magnesium minerals (e.g., feldspar, pyroxene), intensifying groundwater chemical changes compared to natural conditions.  Analysis using the PCA-APCS-MLR model attributes the factors influencing groundwater chemical characteristics in the study area to four main sources: evaporation concentration, water-rock interactions and ion exchange, agricultural pollution, acid production from the oxidation of sulfur-bearing ores, and other sources. Significant spatial differences exist in the coupling relationships between groundwater chemical characteristics (x1), soil characteristics (x2), and fraction vegetation coverage (FVC, y) on the north and south sides of the study area's lakes. The multiple regression models for the three variables in the mining-disturbed and naturally regulated areas, constructed using the EWM and OLS methods, are: yNorth=−210.246x1−37.228x2+124.727 (R2=0.607), ySouth=−142.642x1−60.186x2+105.574 (R2=0.784). These models show that groundwater chemical characteristics are the main driver of FVC changes in mining-disturbed areas, while soil characteristics play a more significant role in natural areas . This study can not only provide a scientific basis for the sustainable development of similar mining areas globally but also provide guidance for ecological management and the rational utilization of water and soil resources in semi-arid coal mining areas.

title: The Bank Liquidity Creation and Equity Capital Puzzle
affiliations: University of South Carolina - Darla Moore School of Business, University of International Business and Economics, Nankai University, HEC Paris and University of South Carolina

detail.title: The Bank Liquidity Creation and Equity Capital Puzzle
detail.abstract: We revisit the bank capital-liquidity creation debate using quarterly US bank data for 20 years from 2003:Q1-2022:Q4, investigating for first time how relations differ for bank outputs versus inputs and for major outputs and inputs. We find a negative overall relation between capital and liquidity creation for small banks, consistent with the Financial Fragility-Crowding Out (FFCO) Hypothesis and a positive relation for large banks, consistent with the Risk Absorption (RA) Hypothesis. Key contributions are that we find much of the explanation of the size-class difference lies in the different effects for outputs versus inputs and for major outputs and inputs.

detail.abstract: The gambler's fallacy is a pervasive cognitive misconception involving randomness and probability. Rooted in mistaken interpretations of statistical laws, this bias leads individuals to expect patterns in truly independent events, especially in gambling and financial decisions. This paper explains the gambler's fallacy using fundamental probability theory, explores real-life consequences, reviews psychological and mathematical research, and suggests educational strategies to reduce its impact. The analysis is grounded in probability theory, statistical laws, and empirical data, with case studies from gambling, finance, and psychological experiments.

title: Talking Tuism and Ruminating on Rules
affiliations: Texas Tech University - Free Market Institute

detail.title: Talking Tuism and Ruminating on Rules
detail.abstract: Humanomics is a research program that, among other aspirations, challenges a pure utility-maximizing or purpose-seeking approach to economics. It posits that moral sentiments and rule-following both offer considerable increases in the explanatory power of economic theory, and critiques the ways that standard mainstream, behavioral, and radically subjectivist economics has treated these subjects. This essay motivates and then asks a series of questions about what humanomics asks of us fellow economists. If moral sentiments are so powerful, why do individuals buy low and sell high in market experiments? How do individuals determine which rules are relevant in different social contexts? Is humanomics subject to the same problem that it accuses mainstream economics of? And what are economists being asked to give up in order to take on this approach to economic theory?

detail.abstract: This systematic literature review synthesizes research on AI procurement governance frameworks specific to customs administration, with particular focus on the Indonesian context. Through a comprehensive analysis of 85 studies published between 2020-2024, this review addresses critical gaps in understanding how customs agencies can effectively govern AI procurement processes. Using a WHO-WHAT-WHEN-HOW analytical framework, we identify key stakeholders, governance elements, implementation stages, and mechanisms for AI procurement governance in customs operations. Findings reveal significant gaps in customs-specific AI procurement frameworks, limited stakeholder coordination mechanisms, and insufficient adaptation of international best practices to developing country contexts. The review contributes to the literature by providing a structured analysis of AI procurement governance challenges and proposing a multi-level governance framework tailored to Indonesian customs modernization efforts. Results inform policy development for customs administrations seeking to implement robust AI procurement governance while maintaining trade facilitation objectives.

title: Better to Lose Together Than to Risk Alone? Loss Aversion and Cooperation in the Prisoner's Dilemma

detail.title: Better to Lose Together Than to Risk Alone? Loss Aversion and Cooperation in the Prisoner's Dilemma

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflicts of interest. This paper was developed as part of the Columbia University Summer Program “Game Theory: A Course in Mathematical Economics” in July 2025. The author participated as a student and submitted this work as the final project of the course. The paper remains a work in progress and part of ongoing personal research and refinement.

detail.abstract: This paper examines a modified version of the classic Prisoner's Dilemma through the lens of behavioral economics. Drawing on the framework of Kahneman and Tversky's Prospect Theory, we incorporate loss aversion into the players' perceived payoffs. We demonstrate that this distortion can alter dominant strategies and lead to an equilibrium that differs from that predicted by traditional game theory. Using a revised matrix of subjective payoffs, we analyze the conditions under which cooperation becomes a more rational strategy in the presence of loss aversion. Our model suggests that seemingly irrational behaviors can encourage more cooperative and stable outcomes, with significant implications for the analysis of economic and social interactions. The integration of bounded rationality into strategic games not only provides a more realistic representation of human decision-making, but also offers new insights for fostering cooperative behavior in conflictual settings.
