detail.title: The Effect of Motivation and Leadership Behavior on the Performance of Employees of the Industry and Trade Service in Makassar City
detail.abstract: This study aims to determine the effect of motivation and leadership behavior on the performance of employees at the Department of Industry and Trade of Makassar City. In hopes of contributing to the improvement of agency performance, through the application of leadership motivation and behavior at the Office of Industry and Trade of Makassar City. The population in this study were all employees of the Department of Industry and Trade of Makassar city as many as 100 people. The number of samples used was 68 civil servants using saturated sampling techniques. Data collection is done using observation and questionnaire methods. The data analysis technique used is multiple regression analysis using the Statistical Product and Service Solution (SPSS) program. The results showed that partially the motivation variable had a positive but not significant effect and leadership behavior had a positive and significant effect. Simultaneously motivation and leadership behavior have a significant effect on the performance of employees in the Department of Industry and Trade of Makassar City. The determination coefficient is 0.553 which indicates that the ability of the independent variable to predict the dependent variable is 55.3%. 44.7% are influenced by other factors not examined.

title: How Do Emerging Market Firms Respond to Environmental Taxation? Evidence from China
affiliations: University of Pittsburgh - Katz Graduate School of Business, University of Waterloo, Xiamen University and Independent

detail.title: How Do Emerging Market Firms Respond to Environmental Taxation? Evidence from China
detail.abstract: Environmental taxation aims to improve firms' environmental performance by increasing the cost of polluting. Different from prior finding that firms in developed countries increase R&D investments in response to environmental taxes, we do not find more investment in green technologies by highly polluting Chinese firms or firms from provinces with higher environmental tax rates after the implementation of China's Environmental Protection Tax Law. Instead, these firms increase their income tax avoidance to offset the additional costs caused by the Environmental Protection Tax. This increase in tax avoidance is more pronounced for firms with greater financial constraints, firms in provinces with higher environmental tax rates and greater emphasis on environmental protection. While the environmental tax, on average, improves polluting firms' environmental performance, this effect is muted for firms that increase their income tax avoidance. Overall, our findings suggest that the role of environmental taxation in promoting environmental sustainability is undermined by Chinese firms' income tax avoidance. Our study provides important policymaking implications by identifying an unintended consequence of environmental taxation in emerging markets and showing how different taxes interact with each other.

detail.abstract: In today's volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous (VUCA) world, traditional business models are increasingly ill-equipped to navigate accelerated change. This paper introduces FLUX, a transformation framework composed of four interlocking dimensions-Fast, Liquid, Uncharted, and eXperimental-designed to help organizations adapt and thrive under conditions of deep uncertainty. We explore its theoretical underpinnings, operational dimensions, and methodological pathways for implementation. The paper further illustrates how FLUX can be embedded in emergent economic models such as the circular, blue, symbiotic, and regenerative economies. Empirical application via living labs is proposed, alongside a research agenda to validate and refine the framework. Additionally, the paper contrasts FLUX with BANI and VUCA 2.0, demonstrating its unique integrative advantages.

detail.title: Settlement Prompts Barnard College to Enforce 'Zero Tolerance' Stance on Antisemitism

declarations.funderStatement: The Perrin Institution at The University of Virginia

detail.abstract: As antisemitism rises on college campuses, Barnard's zero-tolerance settlements signal a shift in how higher education needs to balance civil rights, student protest, identity-based protection, and political expression By Angela Lee Setting the Standard Against Antisemitism In February 2024, a lawsuit was filed on behalf of Jewish and Israeli students who claimed that Barnard College of Columbia University failed to address harassment from pro-Palestinian activities. From this settlement, it required Barnard to establish new oversight mechanisms like an independent antisemitism review board, restrict certain forms of student protest activity, and consider the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance's definition of antisemitism (a non-legally binding working definition that aims to provide clarity and guidance on identifying antisemitism). According to a joint statement by Barnard and the lawyers for two Jewish advocacy groups, Students Against Antisemitism and StandWithUs Center for Legal Justice, mandatory reforms such as staff training, transparent incident reporting, and enforcement of a strict zero-tolerance antisemitism policy are needed. Additionally, Barnard will also appoint a new Title Vl coordinator to investigate discrimination complaints and produce annual reports on antisemitism. As antisemitism is resurfacing among colleges across the nation, colleges must act now or risk legal consequences. Title Vl Enforcement and Federal Pressure Title Vl of the Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination based on race, color, and national origin. In response to increased antisemitism, the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights (OCR) and other federal agencies are taking firmer stances. The violation of Title Vl, for instance, can lead to the loss of federal funding, legal action, and reputational damage. What's happening at Barnard is just one of many other investigations in which universities are pressured to revise their anti-discrimination systems, train staff on hate incidents, and ensure that it is carried out consistently and efficiently. Before this, Title VI enforcement wasn't as prevalent-even with complaints from students about the ongoing protests. Taking actual legal action seems to be the step to start seeing a difference in anti-discriminatory practices. Differentiating Between Freedom of Expression and Hate Speech As institutions start to enforce their policies more strictly, questions about the First Amendment will be referred to often, especially in cases of whether or not the activities happening on campus are a form of expression or considered hate speech. According to Len Saxe, the Klutznick Professor of Contemporary Jewish Studies and director of Brandeis' Cohen Center for Modern Jewish Studies, more than 25% of Jewish students across 50 different private and public universities in America expressed feelings of hostility after the 2014 Gaza conflict, and continuing now after the October 7 conflict as well. The most common form of expression from college students was made through vocal protests.

title: Profit over People? Examining the Environmental and Social Consequences of TNCs in Resource-Rich Regions
affiliations: Spur Legal Freelancing

detail.title: Profit over People? Examining the Environmental and Social Consequences of TNCs in Resource-Rich Regions
detail.abstract: This paper explores the real-world consequences of transnational corporations' activities in resource-rich regions, using Shell's operations in Nigeria's Niger Delta as a central case study. While TNCs are often portrayed as champions of sustainable development, their practices on the ground sometimes tell a different story. The analysis delves into how Shell's environmental and social policies-though commendable on paper-fall short in practice, contributing to long-term ecological damage and social disruption in the communities where they operate. The essay further examines the Nigerian government's response through its Environmental Impact Assessment Act (EIAA), highlighting issues around compliance, enforcement, and legal adequacy. By drawing from legal cases, academic literature, and policy reviews, this work reflects on the tension between economic development and environmental justice. It argues that without stronger oversight and more robust legal reform, profit-driven corporate activity will continue to outweigh the rights and wellbeing of local populations.

title: To What Extent Does Chinese Foreign Aid Shape Economic and Institutional Policies in Pakistan?
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: To What Extent Does Chinese Foreign Aid Shape Economic and Institutional Policies in Pakistan?
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of Chinese assistance on Pakistan's institutional and economic policies by analysing growth, governance, and social outcomes between 2000 and 2021. Drawing on the aid effectiveness literature, particularly Dambisa Moyo's "Dead Aid" and Phyllis R. Pomerantz's "Foreign Aid: Policy and Practice," the study explores competing perspectives on whether aid endorses sustainable development, especially for underdeveloped nations. Using correlation analysis, the study finds an inverse correlation between domestic industrial output and total Chinese aid, suggesting that aid has not stimulated domestic production. Total Chinese aid also has a positive relationship with unemployment in Balochistan, home to one of the most significant projects under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, indicating that extensive infrastructure development through Chinese aid has not fulfilled its promises to create employment. Policy analysis has shown that these effects are forcefully concurred by Pakistan in order to stay afloat. This is evident in the Special Economic Zones Act of 2012, tax exemptions outlined in finance acts, and the realignment of Pakistan's foreign policy. These policies have directly facilitated China's Belt and Road Initiative. As long as China remains a major benefactor, Pakistan's institutional and economic reforms will continue to prioritise the interests of China.

detail.abstract:
The rapid acceleration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) adoption in European banking risk models—particularly in credit scoring and fraud detection—has created unprecedented governance challenges around fairness, explainability, bias mitigation, and regulatory compliance. Recent industry surveys reveal that 75% of large euro area firms are actively using AI in daily business operations, yet only 17% of European banks consider themselves ahead in AI adoption, highlighting a critical readiness gap in the sector. The technical challenges are substantial: research demonstrates that 91% of machine learning models experience performance degradation over time, with model accuracy deteriorating within days of deployment when production data diverges from training datasets. In fraud detection applications, while AI-powered systems achieve impressive 87-94% detection rates and reduce false positives by 40-60% compared to traditional rule-based methods, traditional systems still generate false positive rates exceeding 90% in transaction monitoring, creating a significant operational burden for compliance teams.
As regulatory frameworks such as the EU Artificial Intelligence Act impose stringent requirements with penalties reaching €35 million or 7% of global annual turnover, and with high-risk AI systems requiring full compliance by August 2026, European financial institutions face mounting pressure to develop robust governance frameworks. The financial stakes are considerable: total governance-related costs for an AI model approximate €52,227 annually, combining annual compliance costs of €29,277 and certification costs of €23,000, while the European banking sector's AI spending is projected to grow at a 30.3% compound annual growth rate between 2024 and 2028, reaching over €20 billion by 2028. Despite this significant investment, only 11% of European financial institutions report being prepared for incoming AI regulations, and 29% feel they lag behind their peers in AI adoption, creating an urgent need for structured governance approaches that balance innovation with regulatory compliance.

title: AI as a Scaffold for Innovation, Equity, and Lifelong Learning: Education through the Lens of the Integrated Flexible Approach

detail.title: AI as a Scaffold for Innovation, Equity, and Lifelong Learning: Education through the Lens of the Integrated Flexible Approach
detail.abstract: This paper critically explores how emerging technologies—particularly Artificial Intelligence (AI)—are transforming global education systems in ways that promote innovation, equity, and lifelong learning. Drawing inspiration from Sal Khan’s recent insights and supported by extensive literature, the study situates AI as a scaffold rather than a substitute in the educational ecosystem. Using a flexible-integrated methodological framework grounded in the 10Ps research model, the paper engages with both theoretical perspectives and real-world implementations, highlighting AI’s role in personalized learning, formative assessment, and creative expression. The study also examines structural challenges such as the digital divide, cultural mismatches, and institutional inertia, while presenting policy recommendations to align educational innovation with inclusive and sustainable development goals. Ultimately, the paper contributes to the discourse on the global “eduscape”—a dynamic, interdependent learning environment shaped by technological change and sociocultural diversity.

title: Examining the Regional Economic Integration: Analysis of Cross-border Trade among ASEAN,China, and India
affiliations: Universitas Islam Internasional Indonesia, Universitas Islam Internasional Indonesia and Universitas Islam Internasional Indonesia

detail.title: Examining the Regional Economic Integration: Analysis of Cross-border Trade among ASEAN,China, and India
detail.abstract: Researchers have studied economic integration since the late 20th century as global markets become interconnected. ASEAN, China, and India are critical political, economic, and infrastructural players, with a growing middle class of over 3.50 billion projected to rise as the fourth-largest economy by 2030. This study examines trade policies, GDP, FDI, proximity, and regional agreements to assess trade flows and economic integration. This study uses a gravity model with panel data regression (1999-2023) to examine regional trade flows. The gravity model estimates the impact of economic size and distance on trade volumes, whereas panel data regression evaluates the relationship between trade policies and economic integration. Data include trade statistics from secondary sources. The finding reveals that economic integration improves trade volume through aligned policies and economic interdependencies. The gravity model highlights that economic size and proximity sustain trade flows, whereas FDI shows a positive correlation, indicating the potential for more profound integration; the trade potential model examines how trade policies and economic size affect intra-regional commerce, a topic rarely studied in the literature. This study calculates trade potential, offering insights for policymakers to improve trade efficiency. Unlike past research that has isolated ASEAN, China, and India, this study provides a comprehensive regional perspective. However, these limitations exclude exchange rates, technology, language, tariffs, and post-2023 applicability.

title: From GEO to AIVO: Rethinking Visibility in the AI Era. A Strategic Transition from Generative Engine Optimization to AI Visibility Optimization
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: From GEO to AIVO: Rethinking Visibility in the AI Era. A Strategic Transition from Generative Engine Optimization to AI Visibility Optimization
detail.abstract: For more than a decade, Generative Engine Optimization (GEO) defined how businesses shaped their discoverability across web platforms. GEO optimized content for generative search engines—most notably Google and Bing—through tactics like keyword placement, link-building, and metadata structuring. But today’s digital landscape is no longer search-first. The emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, and Alexa has redefined how people access information. These AI systems do not crawl the web in real time. They generate responses based on trained data, entity relationships, and citation patterns embedded in model weights and knowledge graphs. As a result, GEO is no longer sufficient. In its place, a new benchmark has emerged: AIVO—AI Visibility Optimization. This paper presents a comparative analysis of GEO vs. AIVO, examines the structural shifts in how visibility is achieved in the AI era, and offers a framework for organizations seeking to remain visible in a world no longer indexed by search—but generated by AI.

title: A New Perspective of the Meese-Rogoff Puzzle: Application of Sparse Dynamic Shrinkage
affiliations: University of Melbourne, Monash University - Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics and University of Melbourne

detail.title: A New Perspective of the Meese-Rogoff Puzzle: Application of Sparse Dynamic Shrinkage

declarations.funderStatement: This research was supported by The University of Melbourne’s Research Computing Services and the Petascale Campus Initiative. Maneesoonthorn is supported by the ARC Discovery Grant DP200101414. Yong Song thanks for the support from ARC Discovery Grant DP230100959.

detail.abstract: We propose the Markov Switching Dynamic Shrinkage process (MSDSP), nesting the Dynamic Shrinkage Process (DSP) of Kowal et al. (2019). We revisit the Meese-Rogoff puzzle (Meese and Rogoff, 1983a,b, 1988) by applying the MSDSP to the economic models deemed inferior to the random walk model for exchange rate predictions. The flexibility of the MSDSP model captures the possibility of zero coefficients (sparsity), constant coefficient (dynamic shrinkage), as well as sudden and gradual parameter movements (structural change) in the time-varying parameter model setting. We also apply MSDSP in the context of Bayesian predictive synthesis (BPS) (McAlinn and West, 2019), where dynamic combination schemes exploit the information from the alternative economic models. Our analysis provide a new perspective to the Meese-Rogoff puzzle, illustrating that the economic models, enhanced with the parameter flexibility of the MSDSP, produce predictive distributions that are superior to the random walk model, even when stochastic volatility is considered.

English Abstract: The article substantiates the relevance of the concept of a state’s financial resilience, which – unlike financial stability or soundness – enables a prompt and flexible response to external and internal shocks, particularly under conditions of increasing debt dependence. It is established that financial resilience is more timely than financial stability, as it accounts for dynamic conditions and does not require institutional rigidity. Ensuring financial resilience makes it possible to transform challenges into opportunities in the context of rising public debt and economic growth. The article outlines various approaches to defining the essence of economic and financial resilience and identifies the key components of a state’s financial resilience.

title: Benchmarking The Efforts of Local Governments in Ukraine to Respond to the Wartime Challenges
affiliations: Kyiv School of Economics, Kyiv School of Economics and University of Queensland

detail.title: Benchmarking The Efforts of Local Governments in Ukraine to Respond to the Wartime Challenges
detail.abstract:
Fiscal distress is a common phenomenon in many countries, at both local and national levels. For Ukraine, it has always been a key challenge, particularly in the first decade of its development, and became especially dramatic since the start of the hybrid war in 2014 and rather an existential issue after the full-scale Russia’s invasion in February 2022 (World Bank, 2024). Indeed, the price of the full-scale war is already immense for Ukraine and it continues to increase every day in terms of the damages and losses and fiscal pressure to finance the army, the recovery and reconstruction, besides the usual government spendings. For example, the most recent estimate of destructions or infrastructural damages to Ukraine has reached already USD 155 billion or almost its 2023 GDP (Nivievskyi et al, 2024). The fiscal pressure and a focus on fiscal sustainability in front of the increasing national security challenges and growth perspectives is immense at the national and local levels. The total reconstruction and recovery needs are at USD 486 billion (World Bank, 2024) which makes up more than 2.5 times Ukraine’s 2023 GDP (Nivievskyi et al, 2024). This comes on top of the expenditures on national defense that amounted to 65% of total Ukraine’s budget expenditures ballooned the fiscal deficit to 20.6% of GDP or USD4 billion per month (KSE, 2024).  

Ukraine has been in the process of decentralization reform since 2015. On top of the administrative amalgamation of territorial units, this reform empowered local authorities with more decision power in terms of managing the taxes and expenditures. On the other hand, local governments face more responsibilities and pressure to mobilize their local fiscal resources needed to cope with the current and future challenges. Hence, the focus on the efficient usage of local resources to maximize local fiscal revenues and its regular monitoring is difficult to underestimate these days for Ukraine (IMF, 2022).  In this paper we make a first ever attempt to benchmark tax potential and efforts of local governments in Ukraine that would allow a regular and continued monitoring and be useful for the purposes of informed decision making. This could be an alternative approach to the one that is used by the Government of Ukraine that is essentially a weighted aggregation of the scores on a selection of communities’ variables without a well-grounded methodological foundation. Moreover, there is an alternative, but not official approach that was developed by an expert group in the government that is also essentially an aggregation of the individual scores on a selection of communities’ variables (Kazuik, 2023a). Important, though, is that these two methods produce different results and rankings (Kazuik, 2023b).So such an inconsistency only reinforce one of the key messages of the OECD (2022) that calls for a more robust performance measurement framework and instruments that would support hromadas’ post-war recovery and development.

It is also worth noting that most of the empirical studies on this topic focus on a cross-country analysis of tax effort and potential, lacking evidence at the level of local communities – regions, districts and/or municipalities (see Cyan et al. 2013, Fenochietto and Pessino 2013, Minh Le et al. 2013, Langford and Ohlenburg 2016, Mawejje and Sebudde 2019). Our paper attempts to fill this gap in the literature by focusing on local level within a particular country of interest.

title: Modeling Interregional Migration and Spatial Attractiveness: A Gravity-Based Panel Approach

detail.title: Modeling Interregional Migration and Spatial Attractiveness: A Gravity-Based Panel Approach

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval was not required for this study as it relied exclusively on publicly available aggregated secondary data and did not involve human participants.

detail.abstract: Internal migration plays a pivotal role in shaping regional equity, labor market dynamics, and the spatial allocation of public services. This study employs an augmented gravity model to examine the determinants of interprovincial migration in Mongolia, utilizing balanced panel data spanning the period from 2000 to 2024. The model incorporates a multidimensional set of economic, spatial, social, and environmental variables and applies robust estimation techniques, including Estimated Generalized Least Squares (EGLS) and Seemingly Unrelated Regressions (SUR), to account for heteroskedasticity and cross-equation error correlations. Empirical results confirm that provinces with higher GDP per capita, elevated wage levels, and better access to healthcare attract significantly more immigrants. In contrast, greater distance from the capital and limited employment opportunities function as migration deterrents. Residual-based diagnostics further reveal spatial heterogeneity, indicating that certain provinces, including Khentii, consistently exceed predicted inflow levels, suggesting the influence of unmeasured factors such as regional identity, perceived safety, or cultural embeddedness. Conversely, provinces like Sukhbaatar exhibit persistent negative residuals, reflecting structural barriers, inadequate infrastructure, and limited access to essential services. A comparative assessment of the eastern provinces reinforces these findings, highlighting pronounced differences in regional migration appeal and underscoring the importance of localized development strategies. The study emphasizes that national migration policies must move beyond economic incentives, also to consider quality-of-life factors, ecological resilience, and social infrastructure gaps. While the analysis provides meaningful insights for spatial policy and regional development, it is limited by its reliance on aggregate data and the lack of household-level behavioral information. Future research should adopt mixed-methods approaches, integrating micro-level surveys and spatial econometric techniques to provide a more comprehensive model of migration decisions in transition economies. This study contributes to the migration literature by offering empirically grounded and policy-relevant evidence tailored to the unique context of a sparsely populated developing country.

title: Macroeconomics Equilibrium in the Long Run: A Classical Perspective on National Income, Inflation, Trade, And Unemployment
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: Macroeconomics Equilibrium in the Long Run: A Classical Perspective on National Income, Inflation, Trade, And Unemployment
detail.abstract: This project is based on the Classical theory of macroeconomics, which explains how an economy works in the long run. It assumes that prices, wages and interest rates are flexible, allowing markets to adjust naturally. The aim of the project is to understand how national income, inflation, trade and unemployment reach equilibrium without government involvement. The long-run perspective helps highlight the role of supply-side factors and market-driven stability. It includes analysis of income generation through the production function, role of money in causing inflation, foreign trade balance in an open economy and how economy is corrected through wage flexibility. Key concepts like the quantity Theory of Money and the natural rate of unemployment are applied. Classical models, flow diagrams and labour market's graphs are used to support the concepts. The classical approach shows that the economy is capable of correcting itself over time. This model remains relevant in policy discussions on inflation targeting and fiscal restraint. It provides a strong foundation for long policy thinking focused on inflation control and productivity growth.

detail.abstract: This article analyzes the evolution of Colombia's Social Progress Index (SPI) between 2011 and 2023, assessing its impact on the fulfillment of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). Using a normative and critical approach, the study evaluates SPI dimensions-basic human needs, foundations of well-being, and opportunity-in relation to fundamental rights. It argues that stagnant social progress reflects structural failures in Colombia's development model, impeding the full realization of social, economic, and cultural rights, especially among vulnerable groups. Recommendations for institutional reform and integrated public policies are provided.

title: Contextualizing AI Policy: How Nationally Tailored Strategies Drive Automation and Trade Competitiveness in ASEAN
affiliations: Institute of Development Studies (IDS), Brighton and University of Indonesia

detail.title: Contextualizing AI Policy: How Nationally Tailored Strategies Drive Automation and Trade Competitiveness in ASEAN
detail.abstract: In the AI-driven global economy, should all countries adopt similar policy templates, or must AI strategies be tailored to national contexts to ensure competitiveness? This paper investigates how ASEAN countries have approached AI policymaking amid rising automation and trade integration pressures—and whether these strategies have delivered tangible economic benefits. While technological maturity, as proxied by ICT readiness, is a strong predictor of AI policy adoption, our regression results show that AI policy strength does not have a statistically significant causal impact on either trade competitiveness (measured via Revealed Comparative Advantage in ICT sectors) or structural automation integration (measured via Sensitivity_IO). This disconnect points to a broader insight: many AI strategies in ASEAN remain symbolic, lacking integration into national production systems. Our country-level analysis, however, reveals important exceptions. Countries like Singapore, Malaysia, and to some extent Vietnam that crafted early, sectorally-aligned, and well-structured AI policies show more promising linkages between AI governance and economic transformation. In contrast, other nations have adopted generic or globally modeled policies without tailoring them to domestic industrial or labor market contexts—limiting their impact. Using panel data from 10 ASEAN countries (2015–2024), this paper combines two approaches: (1) a structured review of national AI policies and their alignment with economic goals, and (2) a data-centric analysis using a Two-Stage Least Squares (2SLS) Instrumental Variable model to assess the impact of AI policy strength on trade and automation indicators. The findings suggest that policy presence alone is insufficient—AI governance must be embedded within sector-specific strategies, institutional ecosystems, and productivity agendas. Our results have clear implications for policymakers. First, technological maturity enables policy adoption but does not guarantee impact. Second, context-sensitive, well-implemented AI policies—like those of Singapore—can enhance national competitiveness when aligned with economic priorities. Third, ASEAN must move beyond high-level strategies toward implementation mechanisms that integrate AI into industrial ecosystems and labor force development. As AI reshapes industries, the region’s success will depend not just on adoption, but on strategic alignment, sectoral embedding, and institutional capacity.

detail.abstract: India's burgeoning population can afford an unorganised work force, however, whether the State can accord them formal status of 'Employee' is uncertain. The Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) play a pivotal role in India's rural healthcare delivery, delivering maternal and child healthcare, immunisation, and prevention of diseases. Although they play a critical role, they are defined as 'volunteers' perpetuating economic disparities based upon gender and excluded from formal employment privileges like fixed pay, pensions, and social security. This paper critically analyses their tenuous legal position under Indian labour laws and constitutional provisions, placing their work in the wider care and gig economies. Using International human rights instruments, such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR), and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), the paper shows how India's handling of ASHAs negates core labour rights. The article also contrasts India's model with international best practices, examining structured community health worker (CHW) programs in Brazil, South Africa, Ethiopia, Rwanda, China, and Russia. In contrast to ASHAs, CHWs in these nations are formally trained, paid a fixed salary, and provided social security, ensuring financial security and professional status. India's system based on incentives keeps ASHAs financially vulnerable and open to exploitation, further worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic when they were assigned frontline work without proper compensation or protection. By suggesting harmonisation of India's policies with global standards and acknowledging ASHAs as a part of the public health infrastructure, the government can facilitate equity, dignity, and sustainability of healthcare delivery. Enforcing ASHAs' rights will not only strengthen the workers but also the overall efficacy of India's public health system. While acknowledging, defining, and sufficiently paying CHWs is not all about social justice, it's an inevitable initiative to accomplish the universal health cover.

title: Sustainable Glamping in Greece: Evaluating Viability and Proposing a Strategic Business Plan
affiliations: International Hellenic University (IHU) and International Hellenic University (IHU)

detail.title: Sustainable Glamping in Greece: Evaluating Viability and Proposing a Strategic Business Plan
detail.abstract:
Purpose: The purpose of this paper is: a. To evaluate the sustainability of glamping as a nature-based tourism option in Greece, which offers higher levels of comfort while promoting environmental stewardship, financial feasibility and societal accountability; b. To explore the potential of glamping to strengthen local economies, contribute positively to society and minimize the environmental impact, and c. To propose a sustainable business plan for glamping accommodation in Greece.

Methodology: The study is based on international bibliographic references and secondary data. Furthermore, the authors conduct a comprehensive case study to capture an ideal sustainable business plan for glamping accommodation in Greece. PESTLE and SWOT analyses are also implemented to evaluate the internal and external factors influencing the glamping sector in Greece.

Findings (results): The study reveals that glamping tourism uniquely combines luxurious accommodations, such as upscale tents or yurts, with immersive natural experiences in remote locations like forests or coastal areas. This concept appeals particularly to the rising demand for sustainable and unconventional vacation options, especially among the Gen Z demographic, who seek eco-friendly and authentic travel experiences that go beyond traditional hotel stays.

Key findings emphasize the necessity for developing sustainable, long-lasting business models incorporating green practices, such as using renewable energy sources, minimizing plastic use, and implementing recycling systems. Moreover, fostering community engagement by employing residents and sourcing products from nearby suppliers is identified as a crucial factor for the success of these ventures. Effective business planning must align with initiatives that promote environmental preservation, such as conserving ecosystems and raising visitor awareness about eco challenges, which are essential for the long-term viability of the glamping sector.

Originality/value/suggestions: This study contributes an analysis and empirical assessment of glamping's viability. It identifies good practices for sustainable hospitality and offers insights for investors and operators on developing successful glamping accommodations in Greece. By examining trends and incorporating sustainable business models, the survey provides a strategic outline for glamping that supports ecological sustainability, economic development, and cultural heritage preservation. Future research should focus on refining these strategies and exploring new sustainable tourism opportunities.

detail.title: By Degree(s): Measuring Employer Demand for AI Skills by Educational Requirements

publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) has prompted widespread interest and discussion about its potential to transform the labor market. For workforce development practitioners, a key issue is how AI is changing the nature of work, mainly through changes in the skills workers need to be competitive for the jobs of today and of the future.

In this Workforce Currents, we explore the growth of employer demand for AI skills in online job postings data between 2010 and 2024. Lightcast, a labor analytics firm, provides job postings data that includes several useful features of each posting, such as the skills required to perform the job functions, the education level required, and the occupation title. While other researchers have documented the overall and industry- or occupation-specific growth in AI skill demand, we investigate how AI skill demand has changed for occupations with differing levels of required education. We ask whether the growth in AI skill demand is concentrated in occupations that require a bachelor's degree or higher, or whether AI skill demand is growing even in occupations that require an associate degree or high school diploma. The answer to these questions can inform workers as they choose training programs and help workforce development practitioners align certificate and associate degree curricula to meet the changing needs of employers.

title: The Self And Suffering: Therapeutic Perspectives From Indian Knowledge Systems
affiliations: Sri Balaji Vidyapeeth University and NSHM Knowledge Campus

detail.title: The Self And Suffering: Therapeutic Perspectives From Indian Knowledge Systems

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Nothing to declare.
declarations.funderStatement: Nothing to declare.

detail.abstract:
Indian philosophical and religious traditions view suffering (duhkha) as an intrinsic aspect of existence. The path to liberation (moksha) lies in transcending the karmic cycle, freeing oneself from the bonds of suffering and attaining ultimate peace (sukha). Duhkha signifies inner turmoil and pain, whereas sukha reflects ease, balance and well-being.

Studies comparing Indian and Western perspectives often highlight significant differences in how suffering is understood experienced and addressed. Western perspectives, particularly within medicine and psychology, tend to focus on identifying and mitigating suffering, mostly emphasizing the role of individual factors and medical interventions.

The art and science of Yoga enables the stilling of mental fluctuations through deep non-attachment and transcendence. In this deep quietude of the inner mind, the eternal self (purusha) is realised. Life is then seen as an expression of the greater Self, and in that awakening, we transcend all suffering. This is the ultimate yogic solution to suffering, the discovery of eternal peace and bliss.

Understanding these concepts within ancient Indian Knowledge Systems (IKS) can help clinicians gain a deeper insight into the inner world of their patients. Healthcare professionals worldwide need to realise that “suffering” in the context of IKS is part of a “larger life context" especially for people of Indian origin. Adoption of culturally appropriate methods enhances effectiveness and creates a holistic approach to therapy.

Culture should not be viewed as a rigid barrier or source of division. Human suffering is universal, and clinical psychiatry should focus on shared experiences rather than differences.

detail.abstract: This study analyzes the evolution of Colombia's trade balance between 1948 and 2023, highlighting its structural impact on social development and the guarantee of human rights. Using official data, it examines how persistent deficits affect economic sustainability and the State's capacity to meet the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially in areas such as health, education, and equality. It argues that the trade balance is not only a macroeconomic indicator, but also a reflection of the material conditions necessary for the realization of social rights.

detail.abstract: Recent studies suggest that space activities generate significant economic benefits. This paper attempts to quantify these effects by modeling both business cycle and long-run effects driven by space sector activities. We develop a model in which technologies are shaped by both a dedicated R&D sector and spillovers from space-sector innovations. Using U.S. data from the 1960s to the present day, we analyze patent grants to distinguish between space and core sector technologies. By leveraging the network of patent citations, we further examine the evolving dependence between space and core technologies over time. Our findings highlight the positive impact of the aerospace sector on technological innovation and economic growth, particularly during the 1960s and 1970s.

detail.abstract:
Accounting Theory and the Architecture of Hidden Power challenges the notion that accounting merely reflects economic reality. Instead, it explores how accounting constructs curated visibility that obscures certain power dynamics—especially within tax planning vehicles such as trusts, private corporations, and intergenerational wealth structures.

Using the OECD Pillar Two initiative as a springboard, this paper traces how accounting rules mediate between regulatory ambitions and institutional constraints. It builds a structural analysis of "selective disclosure" and highlights how deferred taxes, asset freezes, and audit independence serve not as technical necessities but as tools in the architecture of fiscal invisibility.

The paper invites a cross-disciplinary reconsideration of accounting not as a neutral information system, but as a mechanism of institutional design—with real consequences for governance, inequality, and global tax justice.

title: Food Choices as Pro-Environmental Behavior: Food Consumption Choices and their Individual "Correlates" in a UK Representative Sample *

keywords: Consumer Behavior. JEL Classification Codes: Q54

detail.abstract: Reducing animal-based food consumption is a viable strategy for mitigating the climate crisis. This study examines the potential environmental impact of dietary choices and the factors influencing attitudes towards dietary change. Specifically, we (i) compare the carbon emissions of plant-based versus less plant-based diets, (ii) assess whether current consumption patterns generate higher emissions than both "reduced" (lower intake of animal products) and "compensated" (lower intake of animal products offset by increased non-animal food consumption) scenarios, and (iii) analyze individual predictors of both the likelihood (extensive margin) and extent (intensive margin) of dietary change. Using survey data from a representative UK sample (N = 300), we find that plant-based diets consistently exhibit lower environmental impact. Reducing animal product consumption significantly lowers emissions, which is not fully offset by compensating choices. Correlational analysis identifies personal norms, ethnicity, income, religion, moral values related to "harm," and family composition as significant predictors of attitudes towards dietary change. Personal norms also account for the extent of dietary shifts. Our findings suggest that policy interventions can promote direct reductions in animal product consumption allowing for compensatory dietary behaviors, while leveraging personal norms as a key driver of change.

detail.abstract: The paper provides prima facie evidence of trade-based money laundering (TBML) by Myanmar's private sector. It shows that while governance and fragility indicators help identify the conditions that enable TBML, mirror trade data can strongly indicate related transactions. The impact of abrupt changes in government regimes on governance and fragility indicators are assessed to underscore how such conditions facilitate TBML. The paper uses mirror trade data to show large-scale financing gaps as well as export smuggling. While direct military rule led to a further deterioration in governance, greater civilian participation in the running of government improved conditions, underscoring the importance of such oversight in the successful control of TBML. Mirror trade data show large under-reporting of Myanmar's imports. Given past sources of external credit and Myanmar's limited capacity to attract additional financing, recorded flows are unlikely to have closed the large financing gaps. Instead, prima facie evidence points to the financing of unrecorded imports using illicit funds generated through the smuggling of Myanmar's natural resources across porous borders. The article makes an important contribution to the literature on money laundering by showing that weak governance and increasing state fragility can create the ecosystem necessary to sustain TBML. Furthermore, mirror trade data reveal large import financing gaps and suggest widespread export smuggling which together provide a prima facie evidence of TBML.

The authors propose a principled logical architecture of a platform for tokenizing the assets of territorial communities and describe step-by-step the use case of issuing tokens from a state asset (RWA).

detail.abstract: This study investigates key behavioral predictors of trust in AI for accounting and financial decision-making, focusing on AI literacy, technological readiness, perceived usefulness, and ethical awareness. Using structural equation modeling, findings reveal that trust and ethical awareness significantly outweigh traditional factors when cognitive styles are considered. Analytical thinkers, in particular, show greater trust in AI systems when ethical considerations are embedded during design and development stages. Based on these insights, we propose a new theoretical model: AIERA (Artificial Intelligence Ethical Readiness & Adoption). AIERA challenges linear acceptance models by incorporating ethical and cognitive dimensions, offering a more nuanced understanding of AI adoption beyond technical familiarity. The study advances current literature by integrating cognitive-behavioral theory with technology acceptance frameworks, moving beyond utilitarian models like TAM. These findings suggest a shift toward AI adoption that is iterative, ethically grounded, and personalized. Implications highlight the urgent need for system developers, accounting educators, and policymakers to integrate cognitive and ethical profiling into AI system development, financial education, and governance frameworks to foster responsible and sustainable innovation in intelligent automation.

title: Partisanship, Information, and Punishment for Misconduct at Work
affiliations: University of Rochester - Simon Business School, University of Rochester - Simon Business School and University of Rochester

detail.title: Partisanship, Information, and Punishment for Misconduct at Work
detail.abstract: We examine whether firms apply partisan standards in responding to employee financial misconduct. Using detailed individual-level data on financial advisers, we find that, following misconduct, advisers who are political minorities at their firms are significantly more likely to depart than non-minority transgressing colleagues at the same firm and time-a pattern we term "partisan punishment standards." This pattern is especially pronounced at firms with low internal information quality. We also document "partisan reporting standards": firms are more likely to publicly disclose misconduct by political minority advisers while remaining relatively silent in other cases. Importantly, political minority advisers are no more likely to commit misconduct or to reoffend. Firms that exhibit partisan punishment practices subsequently experience slower growth. These findings align with models of discrimination based on taste or biased beliefs.

detail.abstract:
Under the second presidency of Donald Trump, the United States has been increasingly resorting to security cooperation as a tool to advance US economic interests, reflecting a broader strategic shift in the way it uses security guarantees as economic leverage.

- In response, US allies such as member states of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) have accelerated their rearmament efforts and moved to reduce their security dependence on Washington. This wave of rearmament among NATO countries is expected to create short-term opportunities for South Korean defense firms.
- However, over the longer term, these benefits may taper off as NATO nations build out their own defense supply chains and deepen intra-alliance cooperation.

At the same time, Trump’s transactional approach to foreign policy, which ties promises of economic and security cooperation to arms sales, is likely to intensify competition in the global defense market. His push to establish a US-centered defense ecosystem raises concerns that the current Korea-US defense cooperation framework could be sidelined.

- The US continues to pressure Seoul to pay more for hosting US troops in Korea; increased costs could lead to delays in joint projects and hinder the qualitative advancement and export sophistication of Korea’s defense industry.

In response, it is essential to swiftly establish lasting cooperation institutions, such as a reciprocal defense procurement agreement (RDP-A), to reinforce Korea-US defense cooperation and identify strategic leverage points, particularly in relation to urgent US supply chain needs.

title: Optimal Dispatch and Impact Analysis of Power–Heat–Gas Integrated Energy Systems Considering Carbon Pricing Schemes
affiliations: Inha University, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Inha University

detail.title: Optimal Dispatch and Impact Analysis of Power–Heat–Gas Integrated Energy Systems Considering Carbon Pricing Schemes
detail.abstract: With the global shift toward carbon neutrality and the implementation of emissions trading systems, analyzing external factors such as emission allocation schemes and energy prices in integrated energy systems has become increasingly important. This paper proposes an optimal dispatch strategy for sector-coupled power–heat–gas integrated energy systems, including renewable energy that considers emission allowance allocation schemes to evaluate the impacts of carbon pricing, economic performance, and environmental sustainability. A linearized integrated energy system model is developed to system marginal price settlements under different allowance allocation schemes, enabling assessment of carbon and cost trade-offs under various policy and market scenarios. System performance is evaluated through sensitivity analyses of sector coupling device efficiency, energy prices, and carbon prices. The results show that excessive improvements in certain efficiency parameters, particularly thermal efficiency in CHP units, can lead to counterproductive outcomes by raising both indirect emissions and operating costs. Through case studies under diverse external scenarios, the study provides practical recommendations for system operators, investors, and policymakers to support affordable and low-carbon energy transitions. The findings underscore the importance of well-designed emission allocation policies and cost-effective investment strategies in achieving climate and energy goals.

detail.abstract: Firms organize their production processes differently, with consequences for various metrics of the economy. A so-far little explored issue is whether and how the deepness of firms, meaning the number of hierarchical levels, affects employment segregation in the labor market. We show how the Duncan index, a widely used measure of segregation, changes as firm organizations become deeper, first in a simplified flow model of the labor market, and then when transition probabilities are endogenized in a simulation model with internal promotions and external worker mobility across firms in a frictional environment. Our results suggest that a new hierarchical level can reduce segregation and serve as a stepping stone for disadvantaged workers in the "bottleneck" part of the career ladder. Yet, a new level can turn into a stumbling block for disadvantaged workers increasing segregation, if it is introduced in parts of the career ladder preceding the "bottleneck".

title: Data-Driven Optimization of Diet Formulation to Enhance Survival and Growth in Japanese Eel (Anguilla Japonica) Larvae
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Japan Fisheries Research and Education Agency, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Data-Driven Optimization of Diet Formulation to Enhance Survival and Growth in Japanese Eel (Anguilla Japonica) Larvae
detail.abstract: Developing an optimal larval diet for Japanese eel (Anguilla japonica) remains a major bottleneck in artificial seedling production due to the limited efficacy of conventional heuristic formulation methods. We implemented a data-driven, human-in-the-loop optimization framework based on Bayesian optimization (BO) and Gaussian process regression (GPR) to systematically refine shark egg yolk-free diets. Across eight sequential feeding trials, the ingredient ratios of seven key components were iteratively adjusted, guided by empirical expert insight. Survival rate and total length (TL) were measured from 6 to 100 days post-hatch (dph). Multi-objective optimization targeted simultaneous improvement in survival and growth during the early (6-40 dph) and late (41-80 dph) periods. The optimized diet formulations achieved survival rates up to 74.9% versus 30.7% in controls and mean TL of 40.1 mm versus 35.2 mm (p < 0.05) at 100 dph. These results were consistently reproduced in independent validation trials. Mechanistic modeling via Random Forest and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) revealed that stage‑specific balancing of yeast extract-derived nutrients and other macronutrient components were critical drivers of improved survival and growth. To our knowledge, this is the first reported application of BO to larval feed optimization in Japanese eel. Our framework integrates probabilistic modeling with expert input to reduce experimental burden and accelerate development of superior larval diet formulations. This approach offers a practical, broadly applicable template for feed innovation across aquaculture species.

title: Positioning Stakeholders in Regional Train Decarbonization Via Network Modeling and Analysis

detail.title: Positioning Stakeholders in Regional Train Decarbonization Via Network Modeling and Analysis
detail.abstract: French regions must settle on a technological alternative for diesel-powered trains to reach the Paris Agreement's targets. This decision process suffers from a complex, multi-actor, unmastered organization, leading to unbalanced power dynamics, lack of information, and loss of efficiency. We address these issues by reorganizing the decision-making process. Interviews with technical experts from regional transport authorities allow us to collect data on stakeholders' contributions and influence. These were used to model the decision process and study interaction dynamics. Our analysis reveals the dominant roles of public entities and strategic industrial stakeholders and highlights the challenges of protecting the decision process from undesired individuals' influences. Notably, we propose reducing private sector influence through actors' organization. This research contributes to methodological development and application for decision support with actor-actor workflows. The proposed framework allows for modeling decision workflows between stakeholders to analyze them and organize their interventions during the decision process.

This paper considers the role universities play in determining their enrollment when faced
with government regulated domestic tuition. Our theoretical framework posits that domestic student enrollment increase and international student enrollment decrease or remain unchanged when domestic tuition increases.
