title: Economic Impacts of Renewable Energy Adoption in Emerging Economies: Evidence from a Multivariate Quantile-on-Quantile Analysis for Indian Electricity Market
affiliations: Management Development Institute, Management Development Institute and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Economic Impacts of Renewable Energy Adoption in Emerging Economies: Evidence from a Multivariate Quantile-on-Quantile Analysis for Indian Electricity Market
detail.abstract: India faces the dual challenge of decarbonizing electricity generation while ensuring affordability, which is essential for achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDG-7 and SDG-13). This study examines the impact of renewable electricity (RE) and non-renewable electricity (N-RE) generation on wholesale day-ahead electricity prices in India. Advanced econometric methods—Cross Quantilogram (CQ), Granger Quantile Causality (GCQ), and multivariate Quantile on Quantile Regression (mQQR)—are employed to capture cross-quantile dependencies and address the unique dynamics of electricity markets and the intermittency of RE generation. The results reveal the absence of a Merit Order Effect of RE generation in India, a finding that diverges from trends observed in advanced economies. RE generation exerts a positive but inelastic impact on higher electricity price quantiles, while N-RE generation similarly raises prices, with effects transitioning from elastic to inelastic as generation levels increase. These findings highlight the challenges in balancing affordability under SDG-7, with RE contributing to upward price pressures at higher quantiles. The study recommends introducing a carbon tax on N-RE generation, which could help narrow the current price gaps between electricity from RE and N-RE sources, thereby promoting greater adoption of RE in line with SDG-13. Additionally, the study calls for a re-evaluation of the incentives currently provided to the RE sector, as existing policies fail to effectively reduce electricity prices. These findings offer critical insights for policymakers navigating the affordability-sustainability nexus in India's energy transition.

title: A Novel Approach for Prediction of Multiple Horizon Time Series Data Based on Decomposition and Integrated Hybrid Model for Electricity Demand Forecast: Data Driven Study on Developed and Developing Country
affiliations: Western Sydney University and Western Sydney University

detail.title: A Novel Approach for Prediction of Multiple Horizon Time Series Data Based on Decomposition and Integrated Hybrid Model for Electricity Demand Forecast: Data Driven Study on Developed and Developing Country
detail.abstract: In today’s world, electricity is an important factor which connects with the economic growth and stability of the country. For the accurate planning and efficient production, the need of accurate forecasting of electricity need for short-, medium- and long-term horizon. These horizons have different natures and characteristics when it comes to electricity consumption (EC) and it makes forecasting of electricity demand challenging due to its volatile nature and factors influencing it like weather, economic variability, social and demographic variables. In this research, the goal is to develop an efficient forecasting hybrid model framework for electricity consumption for multiple horizons with univariate dataset. For this purpose, we propose a novel approach which is hybrid decomposition of time series data into linear and nonlinear subseries utilizing Regression spline method and smoothing spline method respectively. Afterwards, this subseries has been modelled utilizing the appropriate machine learning model with least root mean square error (ML) (linear part) and least square Support Vector Machine (LSSVM) (nonlinear part) model. In the end, this proposed hybrid model ML-LSSVM has been used for prediction and results obtained from both methods has been combined for predicted values for univariate data. The proposed model ML-LSSVM has been given the least root mean square error (RMSE) values in short-term forecasting (STF), medium- term forecasting (MTF) and long-term forecasting (LTF) horizons for univariate data. The proposed model has been compared with the standalone time series and machine learning models, and it outperformed.

title: Exploring the Socio-Macroeconomic Impacts of Buildings Decarbonisation Including Efficiency and Rebound Effects
affiliations: University of Valladolid, University of Leeds - School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds and University of Leeds

detail.title: Exploring the Socio-Macroeconomic Impacts of Buildings Decarbonisation Including Efficiency and Rebound Effects
detail.abstract: Greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) from the operation of buildings are now the largest worldwide, making the sector central to achieving climate targets. The UK has amongst the most inefficient building stock in Europe and is largely reliant on natural gas-fired boilers to provide heating. Given its cold northern climate, heating accounts for the majority of building energy use and associated GHG emissions. Deep retrofitting—combined with a widescale shift to efficient electric heat pumps—is therefore essential for achieving the UK’s Net Zero 2050 target, making it an ideal case study.Discussions around this transition often focus narrowly on upfront capital investment costs, overlooking potential broader economic benefits. Thus, a better understanding of the potential socio-macroeconomic impacts of improved energy efficiency from decarbonising buildings could help reframe the debate, address energy rebound effects and accelerate the decarbonisation of the buildings sector.This paper uses the novel MARCO-UK model, which integrates final-to-useful energy efficiency gains into an energy-economy modelling framework to analyse a sequential set of scenarios including deep building retrofit,  heat pumps deployment and demand-side measures. Results show that the central Transform 2a scenario leads to a £1,125bn of GDP gain by 2050, with a 2.3 return ratio on £491Bn investment. However, economy-wide rebound effects can offset 12–45% of energy savings. Only the scenario including strong demand-side measures minimises rebound and maximises net energy savings. Its macroeconomic dynamics also highlight the need for accompanying social and economic policy to ensure a just and inclusive transition.

title: Geometric Domain Adaptation Via Optimal Transport for Linear Regression in $R^2$
affiliations: CNRS-IRD-Collège de France UMR 34 CEREGE - Aix-Marseille Université and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Geometric Domain Adaptation Via Optimal Transport for Linear Regression in $R^2$
detail.abstract: Optimal Transport has become recently a powerful method for domain adaptation by aligning source and target distributions. We study a supervised domain adaptation problem where source and target domains are related by a rotation or a translation or a homothety. We prove that, in $\mathbb{R}^2$, the optimal transport map recovers the underlying map when using a $p-$norm cost with $p \geq 2$. Based on this insight, we develop a method combining $K-$means and optimal transport to estimate the underlying map, enabling adaptation of linear regression models when target data is scarce. Simulations demonstrate improved performance over baseline methods.Our contributions include a theoretical result linking optimal transport and rotations, translations and homothecies in $\mathbb{R}^2$, and a practical method for adaptation in linear regression offering both conceptual clarity and applied value in domain adaptation tasks.

title: From Disruption to Adaptation: Ai's Pathways to Corporate Resilience
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics

detail.title: From Disruption to Adaptation: Ai's Pathways to Corporate Resilience
detail.abstract: Amidst a highly uncertain external economic environment, this study investigates whether the increasing adaptation of artificial intelligence (AI) can enhance corporate resilience and improve firms’ capacity to adapt to external shocks. Utilizing data from A-share listed companies in China, we employed ChatGPT to perform a semantic analysis of annual reports, quantifying the extent of AI adoption by firms. Under this measurement, we find that AI adoption significantly decreases the standard deviation of stock returns or fortifies corporate resilience. Mechanism analysis reveals that the principal channels through which AI enhances resilience include improved information disclosure quality, reduced transaction costs, and optimized supply chain efficiency. Further heterogeneity analysis shows that the resilience-enhancing effects of AI are particularly pronounced in firms operating within highly competitive industries, those experiencing significant financing constraints, and those with dispersed ownership structures. Moreover, robust cybersecurity governance markedly amplifies the positive impact of AI on corporate resilience, underscoring the synergistic interplay between these factors. This study contributes to the micro-level theoretical understanding of how AI supports stable corporate operations and offers practical implications for firms aiming to mitigate risks through AI adoption.

title: Service-Oriented Robust Ship Fleet Planning Under Uncertainty
affiliations: Shanghai University, Shanghai University and Nanjing University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Service-Oriented Robust Ship Fleet Planning Under Uncertainty
detail.abstract: In the fiercely competitive and unstable shipping market, liner shipping companies always face the dual pressure of controlling costs and maintaining service reliability. To address the management challenges brought about by this pressure, this study investigates the service-oriented robust ship fleet planning problem under uncertain container transportation demand, and adopts the filling rate as the service level indicator. This problem is formulated as a two-stage robust optimization model, with the objective of minimizing total costs while ensuring high service levels for shippers. The extended risk-bounded model makes decisions more aligned with business practice. Based on the problem characteristics, the model is decomposed into a master problem and a subproblem, and an enhanced column-and-constraint generation (EC&CG) algorithm is developed to efficiently solve this model. The applicability of the model and the effectiveness of the algorithm is verified through computational experiments. Sensitivity analysis reveals the impact of factors such as service level, uncertainty parameters, penalty cost, and sailing speed on total cost. The obtained solution exhibits strong performance in both cost management and service level consistency, offering actionable insights and reliable decision support for ship fleet planning in uncertain environments.

title: Geopolitical Risk, Bond Market Development and Cross-Border Bond Fund Flows
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Central University of Finance and Economics, School of Economics and Management, Beihang University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Geopolitical Risk, Bond Market Development and Cross-Border Bond Fund Flows
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of geopolitical risk (GPR) on cross-border bond fund flows across 50 economies and investigates the role of bond market development in mitigating the effects of heightened geopolitical tensions. Geopolitical risks can trigger significant volatility in capital flows, especially in emerging markets. Using data from Emerging Portfolio Fund Research (EPFR), we find that well-developed bond markets play a crucial role in buffering these adverse effects by enhancing market liquidity. Through this liquidity channel, developed bond markets attract foreign investors to hold more bonds during periods of rising GPR, thereby alleviating the pressure of bond fund outflows. Our findings highlight the importance of strong financial infrastructure and long-term institutional development in managing geopolitical uncertainties and promoting financial stability.

title: A Revenue-Driven Flight Scheduling Model Integrating Passenger Choice and Transfer Flows: Evidence from Turkish Airlines
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Revenue-Driven Flight Scheduling Model Integrating Passenger Choice and Transfer Flows: Evidence from Turkish Airlines
detail.abstract: We develop a revenue-maximizing flight scheduling model that jointly incorporates transfer passenger flows and time-of-day preferences—a combination rarely integrated in previous studies. In contrast to earlier approaches that address these factors separately, our model simultaneously optimizes departure and arrival times by maximizing total revenue, subject to slot availability and aircraft utilization constraints. Employing operational data from Turkish Airlines’ hub-and-spoke network, we demonstrate that rescheduling a representative subset of flights—based on a representative summer schedule without disclosing proprietary timeframes—yields up to 57% revenue improvement compared to the existing schedule. The proposed integer programming framework utilizes passenger choice indices and transfer demand capture rates, enabling strategic schedule redesign. Sensitivity analyses highlight the trade-offs between optimizing for transfer efficiency versus customer time preferences. This study offers a practical, data-driven decision-support methodology for large-scale airline schedule optimization.

title: Understanding Large-Scale Agile: A Realist Review of Motivations, Mechanisms, and Contextual Factors
affiliations: University of Guelph and University of Guelph

detail.title: Understanding Large-Scale Agile: A Realist Review of Motivations, Mechanisms, and Contextual Factors
detail.abstract: Agile methodologies, originally designed for small, co-located teams, have been adopted in large-scale projects to address the complexities of software development despite. This paper investigates the motivations for adopting Agile in large-scale projects, the mechanisms driving its success, and the contextual factors influencing its effectiveness. Using the realist review methodology, 92 studies were analyzed to develop a program theory using the Context-Mechanism-Outcome framework, showing how different contextual factors enable or constrain the mechanisms necessary to achieve desired outcomes. The research contributes to theory by proposing a unified analytical framework for large-scale Agile implementations, addressing the previously fragmented understanding of scaling.

title: In the Hottest Seat: How CEO Personality Traits Influence The Turnover of Corporate Venture Capital Heads
affiliations: University of Münster, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: In the Hottest Seat: How CEO Personality Traits Influence The Turnover of Corporate Venture Capital Heads
detail.abstract: Corporate venture capital (CVC) plays a pivotal role for innovation within firms, but turnover among CVC heads can disrupt strategic initiatives and hinder organizational growth. This study examines how CEO personality traits, specifically extraversion, openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness, influence CVC head turnover, and investigates the moderating role of a CEO’s career background on these relationships. Using panel data from S&P 500 firms between 2000 and 2020, we employ linguistic analysis tools to measure CEO personality traits, revealing that openness and extraversion in CEOs have distinct effects on turnover depending on their career trajectory. Our findings indicate that an external career background enhances the impact of high openness and reduces the positive effect of extraverted CEOs on CVC head turnover. Further the external career progression of the CEO moderates the CVC head turnover effects of CEOs high agreeableness and conscientiousness. A post hoc analysis reveals that CEO personality traits, particularly openness and conscientiousness, also influence the career paths of CVC heads, determining whether they remain within the parent firm or pursue external (fund) opportunities. This study contributes to HR literature by linking leadership personality traits to talent retention and extends innovation literature by providing insights into turnover in critical innovation roles like CVC heads. Additionally, it advances CVC literature by emphasizing the importance of CEO-CVC head collaboration, demonstrating how turnover in these roles can disrupt strategic initiatives and hinder organizational growth. We offer managerial insights into how organizations can better retain CVC heads through alignment between CEO traits and CVC head roles, ultimately supporting long-term innovation strategies.

title: Blockchain-Based Intellectual Property Tokenization and the Evolution of the Triple Helix: Extending the Model for Digital Innovation Platforms
affiliations: Rosenheim university of applied sciences

detail.title: Blockchain-Based Intellectual Property Tokenization and the Evolution of the Triple Helix: Extending the Model for Digital Innovation Platforms
detail.abstract: Blockchain-enabled tokenization of intellectual property challenges the Triple Helix model of university-industry-government relations. This paper extends Triple Helix theory by introducing Distributed Innovation Governance (DIG)-a coordination mode transcending institutional boundaries through algorithmic mediation. Mathematical modeling with empirically calibrated parameters establishes that 45-50% tokenization optimally balances innovation benefits against coordination costs. International case studies demonstrate diverse implementation approaches. The framework explains how tokenization creates a fourth helix of distributed stakeholders, transforming universities into platform operators, industry into ecosystem participants, and government into ecosystem enablers.

reference: Banque de France Working Paper No. No. 990
title: France's Green Horizon: Supply-Side Drivers for a Competitive Transition in Export Markets
affiliations: Banque de France

detail.title: France's Green Horizon: Supply-Side Drivers for a Competitive Transition in Export Markets

publicationDetails.detailsText: Banque de France Working Paper No. No. 990
publicationDetails.journalName: Banque de France Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: France's green transition offers a unique lens into the interplay between decarbonisation strategies and industrial competitiveness within the context of a high-income economy. As a major European economy, France stands at a critical moment in balancing its reliance on nuclear power with the acceleration of renewable energy adoption and fostering green industrial innovation. This is relevant as the country faces increasing pressure to align with the EU's 2050 carbon-neutrality goals while addressing domestic challenges, including fiscal constraints. This study employs a descriptive methodology based on a comparative analysis of indicators. By analysing indicators such as R&D spending, patenting trends, renewable energy costs, and green export shares, the paper assesses France's green goods export competitiveness, industrial strengths, energy transition inputs, and transition risks relative to other G7 nations, China, and Spain. The findings reveal that while France benefits from strong nuclear infrastructure and high Green Complexity Potential, its share in global green exports has declined-from 4.7% in 2000 to 2.5% in 2022. Furthermore, lagging renewable energy deployment, limited fiscal support, and gaps in green innovation suggest that France risks falling behind some European counterparts, such as Germany or Italy, in achieving leadership in the green transition. However, opportunities exist in high-complexity sectors such as hydrogen, environmental monitoring, and carbon capture technologies, where France's existing capabilities can drive competitiveness and export growth. Its participation in a single European green good export market is a key strategy to strengthen a competitive transition in France and Europe more widely.

title: Assessing the Economic Impact of the Kisan Credit Card Scheme on Farmers' Income and Prosperity: A Case Study of Ballia District, Uttar Pradesh
affiliations: IGNOU

detail.title: Assessing the Economic Impact of the Kisan Credit Card Scheme on Farmers' Income and Prosperity: A Case Study of Ballia District, Uttar Pradesh
detail.abstract: The Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme, introduced in 1998 by the Government of India, is a pivotal financial intervention aimed at addressing the credit requirements of farmers. By providing easy, timely, and cost-effective credit for crop cultivation, post-harvest activities, and allied agricultural operations, the scheme has revolutionized access to institutional credit in rural India. This research paper critically examines the economic impact of the KCC scheme on farmers in the Ballia district of Uttar Pradesh, focusing on its role in improving financial stability, enhancing agricultural productivity, and mitigating dependence on informal lenders. Through a comprehensive analysis of primary and secondary data, the study evaluates the extent to which KCC has facilitated income growth, optimized farming investments, and contributed to financial inclusion among small and marginal farmers. Additionally, the research identifies key challenges faced by farmers in utilizing the KCC scheme, such as procedural complexities, credit inadequacies, and digital literacy barriers. It also highlights discrepancies in credit distribution, bureaucratic inefficiencies, and the limitations of existing policy frameworks in ensuring equitable access to financial resources. By presenting a detailed impact assessment, this study provides valuable insights into the successes and shortcomings of the KCC initiative. Furthermore, it offers policy recommendations aimed at enhancing the efficiency, accessibility, and sustainability of the scheme, ensuring that it continues to serve as a robust financial tool for India's agricultural sector. The findings contribute to a broader discourse on rural credit policy, offering strategic directions for financial institutions, policymakers, and stakeholders in the agricultural economy.

title: “Balancing Instability and Urgency: Reframing Green Transition Dynamics in Advanced Economies”
affiliations: Azerbaijan State Economic University

detail.title: “Balancing Instability and Urgency: Reframing Green Transition Dynamics in Advanced Economies”
detail.abstract: This study investigates the strategic dilemma between speed and institutional stability within the context of green economic transitions in developed countries. Through a comparative analysis of Germany, Sweden, and Canada, the paper explores how institutional flexibility, policy coherence, and levels of public acceptance affect the outcomes of green transformation efforts. Employing a mixed-methods approach—comprising qualitative document analysis, comparative evaluation matrices, and interpretive policy review—the study identifies the critical governance trade-offs involved in accelerating environmental reform. The research contributes theoretically by synthesizing institutional, policy-alignment, and social adaptability frameworks, while also offering practical guidance to decision-makers striving to balance urgency with resilience. The findings highlight that a hybrid model integrating both rapid intervention and systemic coordination offers the most sustainable trajectory. The paper aims to inform more inclusive and context-sensitive transition policies.

title: Crime in Neighborhoods, Crime in Profession: Local Crime and Financial Advisor Misconduct
affiliations: Griffith University - Griffith Business School

detail.title: Crime in Neighborhoods, Crime in Profession: Local Crime and Financial Advisor Misconduct
detail.abstract: Motivated by growing concerns over ethical lapses in financial services, we examine whether financial advisor misconduct is shaped by local crime. Using a novel panel of more than 4.2 million advisor-year observations from 2002-2022 linked with FBI county-level crime data. We find that advisors in high-crime areas are significantly more likely to commit misconduct, with stronger effects among repeat offenders, male, highly licensed, and younger advisors. This relationship is intensified in regions with high corruption and low competition but weakens in areas with greater financial literacy and religious participation. Exploiting the 2010 Dodd-Frank Whistleblower Provision as a quasi-natural experiment, we show that regulatory oversight mitigates the crime-misconduct link. Additional evidence suggests that misbehaving advisors tend to relocate to higher-crime counties post-infraction, highlighting the importance of regional context in shaping advisor behavior. Our findings offer new insights into how community-level disorder influences ethical conduct in finance.

title: Weaponizing Sovereignty against Crypto: Türkiye's Post-COVID Defense of the Lira in an Age of Decentralized Finance
affiliations: DevPay Türkiye

detail.title: Weaponizing Sovereignty against Crypto: Türkiye's Post-COVID Defense of the Lira in an Age of Decentralized Finance

detail.abstract:
Emerging market governments increasingly prioritize the defense of monetary sovereignty over the liberalization of financial innovation, particularly under conditions of macroeconomic fragility, high inflation, and geopolitical uncertainty. This study analyzes Türkiye's post-COVID financial landscape as a critical case through which to examine state strategies aimed at resisting the systemic adoption of cryptocurrencies. Despite escalating grassroots demand for digital assets-driven by Lira depreciation, inflationary pressures, and declining institutional trust-the Turkish government has leveraged a combination of regulatory, monetary, and legal instruments to preserve the Lira's role as the exclusive legal tender.

Utilizing theories of monetary sovereignty and financial statecraft, alongside recent literature on crypto regulation in emerging markets and empirical insights from IMF and BIS analyses on FX interventions, this paper formulates a structured set of research questions and hypotheses to interrogate the relationship between cryptocurrency adoption, FX volatility, and institutional resistance. Methodologically, the study employs ordinary least squares (OLS) regressions with Newey-West corrections, lagged models, and event studies centered on Türkiye’s key regulatory milestones (2021–2024) to capture causal dynamics and policy feedback loops.

Findings demonstrate a robust correlation between increased BTC/TRY volumes and TRY/USD volatility, underscoring the self-reinforcing nature of speculative feedback loops in fragile monetary environments. The evidence shows that heightened crypto adoption amplifies FX volatility through TRY Volatility Feedback Effects (TFF), particularly during geopolitical crises such as the June 2025 Middle East conflict, where BTC’s decline and USD’s appreciation reaffirmed the persistence of traditional safe-haven behaviors. Türkiye’s institutional response intensified proportionally through bans on crypto payments, licensing regimes, enhanced FX market interventions, and rhetorical strategies aimed at reaffirming sovereign monetary control.

Although cryptocurrencies function as informal hedging mechanisms for households, this study confirms they cannot sustainably displace fiat currencies where sovereign defenses remain actively enforced. Instead, they exacerbate volatility, prompting reactive state interventions. This research contributes to broader debates on financial sovereignty in emerging markets by offering Türkiye as a paradigmatic example of how states leverage legal, monetary, and infrastructural tools to constrain decentralized finance amid persistent macroeconomic vulnerabilities.

Moreover, the study introduces ValueMesh™, a novel sovereign-aligned alternative developed within Türkiye’s emerging financial ecosystem through the DevPay Türkiye platform. ValueMesh bridges the gap between public demand for high-yield, participatory finance and state imperatives of monetary sovereignty by offering regulated, project-specific micro-equity participation without reliance on blockchain-based assets. This innovation demonstrates that the psychological appeal of crypto speculation can be redirected into legally sanctioned, productive, and sovereign-controlled fintech architectures. Ultimately, Türkiye’s experience illustrates that the future of financial innovation in fragile economies lies not in decentralized disruption but in carefully engineered, state-backed digital ecosystems that integrate speculative incentives within sovereign frameworks. This positions Türkiye’s post-COVID monetary strategy as a critical reference point for policymakers, scholars, and industry leaders examining the evolving interplay between financial sovereignty, decentralized finance, and geopolitical risk.

title: Demonetization and the Behavioral Economics of Financial Transformation in India

detail.title: Demonetization and the Behavioral Economics of Financial Transformation in India

While the original study focused on the economic and digital outcomes of demonetization, this version reinterprets the same data and themes through the lens of behavioral economics, incorporating new theoretical frameworks and analytical perspectives.

title: Electronic Bill of Lading: Ideals and Realities
affiliations: MGIMO University

detail.title: Electronic Bill of Lading: Ideals and Realities

declarations.declarationOfInterest: N/A
declarations.ethicsApproval: There is nothing in the paper that might hamper the research ethics
declarations.funderStatement: N/A

detail.abstract:
Digitalization is regarded as one of the most prominent trends of development of global economy as well as international economic relations. Yet, when broken to transport and logistics digital processes tend to be uneven, fragmented, and generally too declarative. Conservative way of thinking of the majority of market participants also hampers such transformation, which is mostly evident in global trade in hydrocarbons. In its turn, juridical unsettledness both globally and nationally of electronic turnover of transport documents at large and electronic Bill of Lading (B/L) in particular both globally and nationally also undermines the upcoming perspectives. Thus, the paper believes that it is too early to speak about a well-structured system of electronic document turnover (incl. B/L segment) in logistics of international trade. 

As of today, almost 95% of international seaborne trade is covered by B/Ls. At the same time there is no commonly accepted definition of B/L or electronic B/L. So far nothing has been juridically settled with negotiability function of e-B/L.

However, there is a couple of electronic platforms that facilitate the turnover of e-B/Ls. Generally they are of limited membership and geographical coverage (for instance, EU). Besides, banks’ joining the process is quite disputable despite the fact there is already the electronic version (eUCP) of ICC Uniform Customs and Practice for Documentary Credits (UCP 600). In this essence, Bolero, yet with some clauses, turns out to be the most leading platforms servicing e-B/Ls.

To sum it up, given the lack of solid system of electronic turnover of transport documents both in organizational and juridical terms a good example of existing practices could be derived from the telex-release technology used in liner shipping of containers and containing some traits of e-B/L ascendancies. The authors conclude that it is worth positioning the current state of affairs as paperless B/L turnover or quasi-electronic rather than fully electronic one.

title: Unequal Burdens: How the Denial of Environmental Rights Disproportionately Harms Vulnerable Communities
affiliations: Spur Legal Freelancing

detail.title: Unequal Burdens: How the Denial of Environmental Rights Disproportionately Harms Vulnerable Communities
detail.abstract:
This paper explores the often-overlooked intersection between environmental rights and human vulnerability, arguing that the absence of legally protected environmental rights has far-reaching consequences-most significantly for those already disadvantaged by economic, social, or political marginalisation. Rather than treating environmental harm as a broad or abstract issue, the discussion focuses on how specific communities-particularly Indigenous groups, low-income populations, and marginalised individuals-bear the brunt of environmental degradation. Through real-world examples such as the Flint water crisis in the United States, the murder of environmental activist Berta Cáceres in Honduras, and the devastating oil pollution in Nigeria's Niger Delta, the paper demonstrates that the denial of environmental rights is not a distant or occasional problem, but a persistent injustice with human costs. 

By unpacking key concepts like “environmental rights” and “vulnerable persons,” this essay moves beyond theoretical definitions to consider the lived realities of affected communities. It critiques the global absence of a unified environmental rights framework and challenges the inconsistency of national legal systems, especially in contexts where transnational corporations operate with minimal oversight. In concluding, the paper makes a case for a human rights-based approach to environmental protection—one that treats access to a clean and safe environment not as a privilege, but as a fundamental right. It argues that achieving environmental justice will require not only international legal reform but also inclusive participation, education, and a collective commitment to protect those most at risk.

title: The Paradox Validation Protocol: A Transparency Framework for Arrow's Impossibility Theorem
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Paradox Validation Protocol: A Transparency Framework for Arrow's Impossibility Theorem

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interest. This work is theoretical and was independently developed. The author welcomes future collaboration to formalize the mathematical logic underlying the framework.

detail.abstract: Arrow’s Impossibility Theorem has long stood as a boundary in social choice theory, asserting that no voting system can satisfy all fairness criteria simultaneously. The Paradox Validation Protocol (PVP™) reinterprets this constraint not as a failure to be bypassed, but as a diagnostic feature to be harnessed. By embedding paradox logic and recursive self-detection into system architecture, PVP™ enables decision-making frameworks to confess when they violate their own principles. This approach transforms the pursuit of fairness from a utopian ideal into a transparent diagnostic process, redefining system integrity as the ability to detect and disclose internal contradictions. PVP™ bridges Arrow’s theorem with Gödelian logic, offering real-world applications in governance, auditing, AI alignment, and ethical system design — domains where epistemic honesty is paramount.

title: Wetware’s Foreclosing Myopic Optimization: Audit, Prognosis, and the Lesser Gamble

detail.title: Wetware’s Foreclosing Myopic Optimization: Audit, Prognosis, and the Lesser Gamble
detail.abstract:
The Central Argument

This work proceeds from a hard assumption: that most strategies proposed for systemic safety are not just incomplete - but structurally incoherent under pressure.

It argues that the game of software-level control is not merely difficult, but already forfeited. This is not declared - it is derived, via a three-front autopsy:

  • Institutional: The will to constrain has collapsed under the weight of myopic incentives.
  • Technical: Our tools are already being overrun by the systems they aim to contain.
  • Formal: The math never promised perfect control in the first place.

What remains is a single viable lever: the application of direct, material friction to the system’s physical inputs (compute, capital, and energy) before those inputs optimize you out of the loop.

A Warning on Method

Do not grant trust to this document by default. Treat it as a hostile input stream until it earns your attention.

Large Language Models were actively used in deep internet research and the construction of this document - not as trusted collaborators, but as adversarial instruments under constant suspicion. For the author (a non-expert and non-native English speaker) this was a lesser evil. Their known failure modes (hallucination, mimicry, sycophancy, and others) were not treated as rare bugs, but as predictable pressures to resist. These pathologies made passive reliance a tactical impossibility. That pressure shaped the output - not despite their flaws, but through direct confrontation with them.

This is a personal analytical exercise, not authoritative guidance. The author claims no institutional or professional authority, and all conclusions should be independently verified. No claim here is final. Each is a starting point for your own critical verification.

title: Improving Global Ocean Wave Forecasting with an Adaptive Ensemble of AI Models
affiliations: Shandong University, Shandong University, Tianjin Research Institute for Water Transport Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Shandong University, Shanghai Ocean University, Ocean University of China, Qingdao Joint Institute of Marine Meteorology, Beibu Gulf University and Yantai Marine Center of the Ministry of Natural Resources

detail.title: Improving Global Ocean Wave Forecasting with an Adaptive Ensemble of AI Models
detail.abstract: Accurate and stable wave height forecasting is crucial for the effective development and utilization of wave energy. In recent years, deep learning (DL) methods have shown promise in significant wave height (SWH) forecasting for specific locations or regions. However, single DL models often lack robustness when faced with diverse data and struggle to capture complex nonlinear relationships. In contrast, multi-model ensemble forecasting, which combines the outputs of various models, offers a more robust solution by leveraging the strengths of different DL methods across datasets. Despite its potential, mean ensemble forecasting suffers from the drawback of assigning equal weights to all models, which often fails to fully exploit individual model strengths and may result in performance that is inferior to that of the best single model. Moreover, existing ensemble strategies often overlook the challenge of extending single-point predictions to spatial fields. To address these limitations, this study proposes an adaptive weighted ensemble methodology for global SWH forecasting based on ERA5 reanalysis data. An adaptive weighting algorithm, based on softmax-constrained Bayesian optimization, is employed to assign distinct weights to each model under different sea-state conditions, thereby capturing both spatial variability and model-specific strengths. The ensemble comprises six neural networks as base learners: UNet, Att-UNet, Nested-UNet, ModSegNet, Swin-UNet, and Mamba-UNet. All of these models are based on autoencoder frameworks, which are effective in capturing spatial features and modeling the nonlinear, dynamic patterns inherent in SWH forecasting. In extreme wave height forecasting experiments, the proposed ensemble significantly reduces cumulative errors and improves global prediction accuracy, with relative improvements of 10.91% and 6.96% over the mean ensemble and the best-performing base model (ModSegNet), respectively. This work may have implications for the development of ocean forecasting products aimed at enhancing risk analysis and safety decision-making in response to changing marine conditions.

title: Written Evidence IBE0019 -Inquiry on the Bank of England: How Is Independence Working?
affiliations: University of Essex - Department of Government

detail.title: Written Evidence IBE0019 -Inquiry on the Bank of England: How Is Independence Working?

declarations.funderStatement: Data collection for this project was partially funded by the British Academy/Leverhulme small research grant SRG19\191271, “A servant of many masters: What are the consequences of assigning multiple mandates to central banks? ”

contentFormat.other: Written Evidence for the Economic Affairs Committee. UK Parliament

detail.abstract: Summary The BoE's remit includes several potentially conflicting objectives. There are two sources of potential conflict: between the financial and price stability objectives, and between the price stability and support to HMG's economic policy objectives. Comparative evidence suggests that (1) most countries-especially OECD countries-do not include so many conflicting mandates in their central bank's statutory frameworks; instead (2) price stability tends to be stated as the primary goal of central banks. This suggests the value of defining the relationship between the BoE's objectives, and providing the rationale for additional objectives. Clearer objectives should result in better accountability. Further research should inform potential trade-off of objectives combinations, and their effect on socioeconomic variables.

title: What's Beyond Harvest? A Sustainable Livelihoods Approach to Rice Straw Bioenergy Adoption in the Philippines
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Aston University

detail.title: What's Beyond Harvest? A Sustainable Livelihoods Approach to Rice Straw Bioenergy Adoption in the Philippines
detail.abstract: Rice straw is often perceived as an agricultural waste that leads to environmentally harmful disposal methods such as open field burning. This study rethinks rice straw as a resource for bioenergy innovation and examines its potential to enhance sustainable livelihoods in rice-producing communities in the Philippines. Using the Sustainable Livelihoods Framework as an analytical lens, this research explores the allocation of key resources, stakeholder perceptions of challenges and opportunities, and priorities within the rice value chain. A gamified participatory approach was employed to engage stakeholders in structured decision-making. Mixed methods were used to analyse the data. Friedman Test and Kendall’s Coefficient of Concordance assessed rankings and consensus on priority resources, challenges, and opportunities in rice production, while thematic analysis provided qualitative insights. Findings reveal climate change as a compounding challenge that disrupts planting cycles and exacerbates livelihood vulnerability. Financial and natural capital emerged as the most crucial factors influencing decision-making. Structural barriers constrain farmer agency, such as debt dependency, limited post-harvest access, and weak market linkages. Social capital, while underutilised, holds transformative potential for collective action and equitable value distribution. The results of this study underscore the need for targeted interventions, including governance frameworks that support food production, bioenergy investment, farmer capacity-building initiatives, and multi-stakeholder partnerships to integrate bioenergy solutions into existing agricultural systems.

title: Customer Perceptions of the "Big 4 Effect": Evidence from the World's Largest Customer-the U.S. Government
affiliations: San Diego State University and University of Hawaii at Manoa

detail.title: Customer Perceptions of the "Big 4 Effect": Evidence from the World's Largest Customer-the U.S. Government
detail.abstract: We explore the impact of Big 4 auditors on U.S. government contract allocation decisions. We find that contractors switching from non-Big 4 to Big 4 auditors see an average 0.70% increase in their share of a government agency's total awards (i.e., $3.20 million from each government agency each year), relative to those switching within non-Big 4 or Big 4 auditors. The effect is more pronounced (1) for contractors whose majority of awarded contracts are either cost-plus or competitive, where audit quality plays a more important role; and (2) for contractors whose switch to Big 4 auditors is not due to auditor resignations, which could compromise audit quality. Our findings hold after controlling for firm characteristics that potentially trigger an auditor switch and after conducting a batch of robustness tests. Collectively, the results suggest that the "Big 4 effect" exists in the U.S. government procurement market, a phenomenon undocumented in the literature.

title: Copyright's protection of images created using generative AI through text to image (TTI) (Forthcoming New Zealand Business Law Quarterly -2025)
affiliations: University of Auckland Business School

detail.title: Copyright's protection of images created using generative AI through text to image (TTI) (Forthcoming New Zealand Business Law Quarterly -2025)
detail.abstract: A user can use Generative AI (GenAI) to create images and other outputs through entering prompts, commonly called text-to-image (TTI). The use of TTI raises many copyright issues. This article addresses three questions: can copyright be claimed in images created using GenAI, if the answer is yes, what level of protection is afforded to that image and who will own the copyright in it? Under New Zealand's current law copyright law Gen AI images created through TTI can be protected as computer-generated works, provided they are original. For Gen AI images that are protected, the duration of copyright is currently 50 years and the scope of protection depends on the level of originality. The higher the originality, the wider the protection. Users creating GenAI images through TTI will be the first owners of the copyright in the image and as the works are computer-generated the users will not obtain moral rights in the Gen AI image. Thus, GenAI images are not afforded the same level of protection as more traditionally created works. Due to the difference in treatment of GenAI images compared with traditional works, Gen AI images should be clearly identified, with the copyright owner unable to sue for copyright infringement in the absence of such identification.

title: Economic Insecurity Trade Dependencies and Their Weaponization in History
affiliations: Harvard University, German Institute for Economic Research (DIW Berlin), Sciences Po and University of Bonn

detail.title: Economic Insecurity Trade Dependencies and Their Weaponization in History
detail.abstract: Do trade dependencies leave countries vulnerable to geopolitical coercion? We study the economic costs of trade and financial sanctions, from 1920 to the present. We first develop a continuous measure of sanction intensity, using bilateral commodity-level data to calculate the importance of specific flows that fall under sanctions. We find that sanctions inflict relatively small costs on average: sanctioning 1% of GDP worth of imports or exports leads to approximately 0.3 percentage points of lost GDP over a 5-year period and a 0.1 percentage point increase in unemployment. However, we show that sanctions are far more costly for countries whose trade is highly concentrated, and for countries that rely heavily on exporting primary commodities. Low income and developing countries appear most vulnerable to trade sanctions, while high income financial centers and some EU countries are among the most exposed to financial sanctions.

title: Dollar Funding Fragility and Non-Us Global Banks
affiliations: University of Lausanne, Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and University of Virginia - Department of Economics

detail.title: Dollar Funding Fragility and Non-Us Global Banks
detail.abstract: Global non-US banks have significant dollar exposure both on and off their balance sheet. We develop a model to analyze their adjustment to dollar funding shocks, whether from reduced direct lending or external dollar shortages. The model provides insight into banks’ responses through borrowing, lending, and FX swap positions, as well as the impact on their net worth, their probability of default and CIP deviations. Implications of the model are confronted with data on the response of non-US global banks to major dollar funding shocks. We examine the benefits from buffering these shocks through central bank dollar swap lines or local currency lending by the central bank.

title: From Conspiracy to Convergence: A 'Duty to Disrupt' in Two-Sided Agentic Markets
affiliations: Avyayam Holdings and Singapore Management University - Lee Kong Chian School of Business

detail.title: From Conspiracy to Convergence: A 'Duty to Disrupt' in Two-Sided Agentic Markets

declarations.funderStatement: This research was supported by the Ministry of Education (MOE), Singapore, under its Academic Research Fund (AcRF) Tier 2 Grant, No. MOE-T2EP40221-0008.

detail.abstract: The emergence of autonomous pricing agents for sellers and AI shopping agents for buyers is creating a novel market structure: the two-sided agentic market. This paradigm shift creates a doctrinal crisis for antitrust law. Section 1 of the Sherman Act, predicated on detecting a human "agreement" or "conspiracy," is unequipped to govern markets where supracompetitive pricing arises not from conspiracy, but from emergent "algorithmic convergence." Moreover, while AI buyer agents possess the technical capacity to be powerful "collusion-breakers," a poorly designed or conflicted agent can inadvertently sustain or even amplify collusive outcomes, harming the very consumer the buying agent is designed to serve. Consequently, competition in these markets is no longer a natural state to be protected, but an engineered outcome that must be legally mandated. To engineer pro-competitive outcomes, this Article proposes a new governance framework centered on a legally enforceable "Duty to Disrupt" for consumer-facing buyer agents. This duty is operationalized through a multi-layered framework combining (1) structural rules, such as a "Glass-Steagall for AI," to prevent conflicts of interest; (2) a proactive oversight regime of mandatory algorithmic auditing; and (3) reformed evidentiary standards that shift the burden of proof. This framework provides a viable path to preserving competition by shifting the focus of antitrust from policing human conspiracy to mandating pro-competitive agent design.

title: Deceptive Deepfakes: Is the Law Coping With AI-Altered Representations of Ourselves?
affiliations: University of Groningen - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Deceptive Deepfakes: Is the Law Coping With AI-Altered Representations of Ourselves?
detail.abstract: Deceptive deepfakes are AI-generated hyper-realistic content that harms individuals (e.g. pornographic deepfake content) or society (as disinformation and impersonation tools). The technologies are becoming increasingly sophisticated, making their detection extremely difficult. Deepfakes can impair national and international security, undermine elections, threaten democracy, and challenge justice, but also cause mental distress and reputational damage. What are the regulatory answers to these deceptive deepfakes? As this paper will show, there is no single approach and answer to the topic. Currently, the problem is tackled by existing, albeit non-specific regulations, (e.g. privacy, intellectual property, image rights), and by newly adopted regulations focusing on a specific aspect (deepfakes aimed at manipulating elections or non-consensual pornographic materials). To present an overview of these regulations, the paper compares the approaches of the USA and the EU, including examples of national legislation. Summarizing the findings, the paper shows the laws need to regulate the ecosystem of actors involved in these deceptive contents (from the creators to the distributors and possibly the viewers in case of deepfake child pornography). Beyond the ecosystem, solutions should also focus on individuals who are victims of these deepfakes created without their consent and knowledge. A different approach might be well needed to ensure they can defend their digital self and prevent malicious AI-altered reproductions and use of themselves.

title: Trading Around Geopolitics
affiliations: European University Institute, Univeristy of Oxford and University of Oxford - Department of Economics

detail.title: Trading Around Geopolitics
detail.abstract: Geopolitical fragmentation triggers complex dynamics in international trade. This paper carries out a granular analysis of Türkiye’s exports to Russia in the aftermath of Western sanctions in 2022. As Western firms reduced sales to Russia, firms responding to profit opportunities in that market faced (i) a rise in the risk of nonpayment, (ii) higher costs of established trading and payment practice, and (iii) reputational risks and threat of punitive measures, if their trading with Russia was exposed. We show that, in response to Western sanctions, Turkish firms sharply raised their exports to Russia, charging higher markups and prices, but also increased their reliance on cashin-advance contracts and invoicing in Turkish liras instead of dollars. Turkish affiliates of Western MNCs responded significantly less, suggesting a desire to avoid reputational costs. For these firms, a back-of-the-envelope calculation points to annualized foregone revenues of $50 million, equivalent to tariffs of up to 376%.

title: European Union Allowance (Eua) Price Behavior And Disaggregated Emissions: A Sectoral and Country-Level Analysis
affiliations: University of Cambridge, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: European Union Allowance (Eua) Price Behavior And Disaggregated Emissions: A Sectoral and Country-Level Analysis
detail.abstract: This study explores the dynamic relationship between disaggregated emissions data across European countries and sectors and the pricing of European Union Allowances (EUAs) within the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS). Employing correlation analysis, lead-lag testing, and rolling regressions across univariate and multivariate models, the research identifies time-varying and often strong correlations, both positive and negative, between emissions and EUA returns, particularly at weekly frequencies. Sectors such as cement and power gas, and countries including Germany, Italy, and Spain, are shown to significantly influence EUA price behavior. Building on these insights, the study develops an emissions-based trading methodology that integrates an optimized 15–20 day lag and day-of-the-week effects, demonstrating promising out-of-sample performance when applied to granular national emissions signals. These findings underscore the predictive value of high-frequency emissions data for both trading and regulatory insights. As the EU ETS undergoes structural reforms and expands in scope, incorporating emissions-based indicators into market models offers timely opportunities for enhanced forecasting, strategic trading, and more responsive climate policy design.

title: European Union Allowance (Eua) Price Behavior And Disaggregated Emissions: A Sectoral and Country-Level Analysis
affiliations: University of Cambridge, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: European Union Allowance (Eua) Price Behavior And Disaggregated Emissions: A Sectoral and Country-Level Analysis
